   761.01 DEFINITIONS.
   Unless otherwise expressly stated, when used in this chapter the following
terms shall be defined as follows:
   (a)   "Certificate of public convenience and necessity" means an
authorization provided by the City to a taxicab company permitting it to engage
in the business of operating a specified number of taxicabs within the City
upon specified terms and conditions and in accordance with the provisions of
this chapter.
   (b)   "Controlled substance" means a drug, compound, mixture, preparation or
substance included in Schedules I, II, III, IV or V as set forth in Ohio R.C.
Chapter 3719.
   (c)   "Driver" means any person authorized and assigned to drive a taxicab,
and includes every person actually in charge of the operation as the chauffeur
of a taxicab, whether as owner, agent, subagent, servant, independent
contractor to or employee of the owner.
   (d)   "Owner or operator" means any person, firm or corporation who or which
has control, direction of operation, maintenance or the benefit of the
collection of revenue derived from the operation of a taxicab as herein
defined, on or over the streets of the City, whether as owner, licensee, bailee
or otherwise, except a driver as hereinafter defined.
   (e)   "Passenger" means any person who has engaged or ordered a taxicab or
who is being carried in a taxicab, for whose carriage a charge is made or might
lawfully be made.
   (f)   "Taxicab" means a vehicle offered for or operated for hire, donations
or any other form of compensation by a person(s) who seeks to purchase
transportation from one point to another without reference to any prescribed
route. "Taxicab," as defined in this chapter, does not include any of the
following:
      (1)   Vehicles, such as but not limited to limousines, which are
exclusively for hire in connection with special or ceremonial events such as
weddings, high school proms, transportation of dignitaries, anniversaries or
funerals;
         (Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
      (2)   Vehicles such as, but not limited to, buses which operate upon City
streets by virtue of a franchise or revocable permit granted by Council
pursuant to Sections 015.126 or 015.127 of the Hamilton Charter.
         (Ord. 93-6-66. Passed 6-9-93.)
      (3)   Private vehicle(s) belonging to the passenger which are driven by a
chauffeur; the chauffeur being the employee of the passenger and therefore
capable of being hired or fired from employment by the passenger.
      (4)   Vehicles engaged exclusively in the transportation of freight; or
      (5)   The transportation of persons characterized by the use of only
one's private motor vehicle, titled in the driver's name and operated
exclusively on a irregular, infrequent or occasional basis to transport
friends, relatives or acquaintances of the vehicle owner/driver, with the
owner/driver neither having or using any other means of advertisement
suggesting an intention, desire or willingness to operate a taxicab company,
and which activity is not connected in any manner with a passenger or freight
transportation business.
   (g)   "Taxicab company" means every corporation, company, association, joint
stock association, person, firm or copartnership, its lessees, trustees,
receivers or trustees appointed by any court whatsoever, owning, controlling,
operating or managing any taxicab.
   (h)   "Taximeter" means any mechanical or electronic instrument or device,
geared either to a front wheel or to the drive shaft in the rear of the
transmission, by which instrument or device the charge for hire for a taxicab
is mechanically or electronically calculated, and on which such charge is
clearly indicated as it accrues.
   (i)   "Wheelchair cab" means any motor vehicle specially designed for
carrying passengers in wheelchairs for hire, not over fixed routes or between
fixed termini, operated by a driver other than a passenger and not his
employee.
      (Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.02 APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to taxicabs from other
jurisdictions, and having no Hamilton City license, bringing passengers into
the City. But this chapter shall apply and no operator or driver of any taxicab
shall solicit or accept any passengers within the City of Hamilton, for any
destination without first obtaining the necessary certificate and licenses
required by this chapter.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.03 MILEAGE RATES.
   Unless at the beginning of a trip the passenger stipulates an hourly rate or
a trip rate, no person shall charge any fare, fee or other compensation for the
use of a taxicab determined or calculated otherwise than by a taximeter at
rates not in excess of the following:
   (a)   For the first mile traveled in response to a call, no charge;
   (b)   For each half-mile additional traveled in response to a call, no
charge;
   (c)   For the first one-eighth mile traveled with one passenger, a maximum
of two dollars and ninety-nine cents ($2.99);
   (d)   For each additional one-eighth mile traveled, twenty-three cents
(23¢);
   (e)   For each minute of waiting time between the time of arrival appointed
by the passenger and the time of arrival at the destination of the passenger,
during which time the taxicab is standing at the request, direction or fault of
the passenger, twenty cents (20¢);
   (f)   For each passenger on any trip in addition to the first passenger, no
charge;
   (g)   For any mileage outside the corporate limits of the City, twenty-five
cents (25¢) per mile.
   The fees set forth in subsections (c) and (d) shall be adjusted annually,
beginning in the year 2010, based upon changes in the local Consumer Price
Index (CPI). Such adjustments shall become effective the first day of February
of each year.
(Ord. 2008-7-71. Passed 7-23-08.)
   761.04 HOURLY RATES.
   Any passenger engaging a taxicab may stipulate the use of an hourly rate, as
determined by the operator, during his use of such vehicle, and it shall be
unlawful for the operator or driver to refuse to serve at an hourly rate, which
shall be the same regardless of the number of passengers carried, unless the
passenger expressly ordered and was furnished a vehicle seating more than five
passengers, provided that the hourly rate is consistent for like passengers
similarly situated. (Ord. 97-3-22. Passed 3-12-97.)
   761.041 INTRA-CITY FLAT RATE SERVICE.
   (a)   Notwithstanding any other rates set forth herein, there is hereby
established and recognized an intra-City flat rate transportation service and
fare. The operator of a flat-rate transportation service shall be the holder of
a certificate of public convenience and necessity as provided in this chapter
and must satisfy all the provisions for the operation of a vehicle in
connection with the operation of a flat rate transportation service except the
following provisions:
      (1)   Section
761.21(c) requiring that the full name, monogram or insignia of the
transportation service company be displayed on each side and rear of each
vehicle in letters at least three inches high, or in the case of a monogram or
insignia, not less than eight inches high, shall not be required for vehicles
while engaged in flat rate service.
      (2)   Section
761.23 requiring continuous service shall not apply to flat rate service. The
minimum hours of operation of an intra-City flat rate transportation service
shall be Monday-Friday, 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., excluding federal holidays.
      (3)   Subsection
761.31(k) requiring a lighted sign atop the exterior of the vehicle which shall
not be required for vehicles while engaged in flat rate service.
      (4)   Section
761.35 requiring a taximeter shall not be required for vehicles while engaged
in flat rate service.
      (5)   Section
761.09 insofar as amendments to a certificate of public convenience and
necessity are concerned.
      (6)   Section
761.21 relating to a color scheme shall not be required for vehicles while
engaged in flat rate service.
         (Ord. 96-2-21. Passed 2-28-96.)
   (b)   Intra-city flat rate transportation service shall be available to
passengers between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. from a point within the
corporate limits of the City of Hamilton to another point within said corporate
limits regardless of distance at a fare to be determined by the operator of the
flat-rate transportation service, provided that the fare is consistent for like
passengers similarly situated.
   More than one passenger may be transported in a single trip, and more than
one passenger may be picked up or dropped off during a trip.
   (c)   The City Manager, or his designate, is hereby authorized to establish
a system of rules and regulations and institute a process for the selling and
redemption of credit tokens for the purpose of defraying all or part of the
flat rate fare referenced in subsection (b) hereof. A credit token shall be
worth three dollars ($3.00) per trip to a qualified passenger who:
      (1)   Presents the vehicle operator with a credit token purchased from
the City of Hamilton,
      (2)   Signs the flat rate vehicle operator's trip sheet indicating his
identity, address, and telephone, and
      (3)   Indicates the street address of the embarking and disembarking
points, and
      (4)   Pays to the operator the difference between the worth of the token
and the fare determined by the operator as referenced in subsection (b) hereof.
   Each qualified passenger who presents such a token on an intra-City trip
shall be entitled a credit of three dollars ($3.00) on the flat rate fare
established by subsection (b) hereof. The maximum discount available to each
qualified passenger per intra-City flat rate fare trip shall be three dollars
($3.00). (Ord. 97-3-22. Passed 3-12-97.)
   (d)   A "qualified passenger or qualified person" eligible to use a credit
token must meet one or more of the following definitions:
      (1)   "Elderly" means any person sixty-five (65) years of age or older.
      (2)   "Disabled" means any person with a physical or mental disability
which is a substantial handicap to employment and which is of a nature that
vocational rehabilitation services may reasonably be expected to render him fit
to engage in a gainful occupation consistent with his capacities and abilities,
and any person with a physical or mental disability that constitutes a
substantial handicap to employment for whom vocational rehabilitation services
are necessary to determine his rehabilitation potential.
   (e)   The operator of a intra-City flat rate vehicle, who would otherwise
constitute a qualified passenger or qualified person, shall not be entitled to
utilize credit tokens while engaged in the operation of a flat rate vehicle.
   (f)   Misuse or abuse of the intra-City flat rate token system shall be
grounds to revoke or suspend the vehicle operator's license or the certificate
of public convenience and necessity of any parties engaged in such abuse or
misuse.
   (g)   The following rules shall apply to intra-City flat rate transportation
service:
      (1)   All certificate of public convenience and necessity holders and all
operators of intra-City flat rate transportation vehicles shall accept transit
tokens in lieu of actual cash payment equal to three dollars ($3.00) for all
intra-City flat rate fares. The City shall not provide reimbursement for
transit tokens in lieu of actual cash payment equal to three dollars ($3.00)
for any fare where the point of embarking lies within the City of Hamilton but
the point of disembarking lies outside the City of Hamilton.
      (2)   No holder of a certificate of public convenience and necessity
holder or operator of intra-City flat rate transportation vehicles will
increase his usual and customary fare for a contracted ride merely because the
transported individual makes payment by means of a credit token.
      (3)   No holder of a certificate of public convenience and necessity, and
no operator of an intra-City flat rate transportation vehicle may purchase,
sell or otherwise obtain credit tokens from any token vendors.
      (4)   No holder of a certificate of public convenience and necessity and
no operator of intra-City flat rate transportation vehicle shall submit any
credit tokens for reimbursement unless such credit tokens were received by the
operator and certificate holder as a result of providing actual intra- City
transportation services to a qualified passenger, which passenger tendered a
transit token in full or partial payment for the contracted intra- City flat
rate trip.
      (5)   No holder of a certificate of public convenience and necessity and
no operator of an intra-City flat rate vehicle shall be entitled to
reimbursement for any transit token unless it is accompanied by a signed daily
trip record showing when, from who, and the points of embarking and
disembarking for all credit tokens received.
      (6)   A holder of a certificate of public convenience and necessity and
all operators of intra-City flat rate transportation service vehicles shall
comply with Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 US 2000 (d)) and will
not deny transportation to any person on the grounds of race, color, or
national origin. All certificate of public convenience and necessity holders
and all operators of intra-City flat rate transportation service vehicles
further argree to comply with Title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, Department
of Transportation, Subtitle A, office of the Secretary, Part 27, entitled "Non-
discrimination on the Basis of Handicap in Programs and Activities Receiving or
Benefiting from Federal Financial Assistance", and, toward that end, will not
deny transportation services to any handicapped person solely by reason of his
or her handicap.
         (Ord. 96-2-21. Passed 2-28-96.)
   761.05 WHEELCHAIR TAXICABS; RATES
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Former Section
761.05 was repealed by Ordinance 97-3-22, passed March 12, 1997.)
   761.06 SANITARY CONDITION.
   (a)   The interior of every taxicab shall at all times be kept in a clean
and sanitary condition, which shall include, but not be limited to, keeping the
interior of the vehicle free of garbage, litter, refuse and rubbish as defined
in Chapter
1909 and
1931 of the Codified Ordinances.
   (b)   A violation of this section, after reasonable notice to the operator
and an opportunity duly afforded to comply therewith, shall be grounds for
suspension or revocation of the certificate of public convenience and necessity
or the taxicab license.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.07 CERTIFICATE REQUIRED TO OPERATE A TAXICAB COMPANY.
   No owner shall operate a taxicab or taxicab company within or from the City
unless he is the holder of a certificate of public convenience and necessity to
operate issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.08 APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE.
   Any person desiring to initially secure or subsequently amend a certificate
of public convenience and necessity shall file with the City Manager, or his
designate, a written application therefor, on a form to be provided by the
City. The application shall be in affidavit form and contain the following
information:
   (a)   The full name, age and residence of the applicant, if it is a sole
proprietorship. If the applicant is a partnership, the full name, age and
residence of each of the partners and a balance sheet for the most recently
ended business year. If a corporation, the full name of the corporation and its
principal place of business, together with the full name of its principal
officers, and a statement of the names and addresses of the shareholders, if
there are less than ten, together with the number and par value of shares
belonging to each, and a copy of the applicant corporation's certificate of
incorporation;
   (b)   The name under which the applicant will do business;
   (c)   The type of vehicles which are to be used in service, with information
as to age, mileage, carrying capacity; the color scheme, local symbols to be
used together with all other lettering or marks proposed to be used by the
applicant on the vehicle;
   (d)   The number of taxicabs proposed to be used and a statement that the
applicant is aware of the rate of fare to be charged and the method of charging
the same pursuant to this chapter;
   (e)   A certificate of insurance executed by a duly licensed representative
of an insurance company licensed and admitted to sell motor vehicle insurance
in the State insuring all taxicabs of the owner or operator in conformity with
all requirements contained in this chapter;
   (f)   The City Manager, or his designate, may, in the exercise of sound
discretion, require such other information as to the applicant's financial or
other fitness to safely conduct the operation of a taxicab service in the City,
including an inquiry into whether the applicant is otherwise indebted to the
City or in default upon an indebtedness to the City; and
   (g)   The application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application
fee of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) to cover the expense of the City
in investigating the applicant, serving notice of public hearing, and
considering the granting or denial of the certificate sought by the applicant.
Any person possessing a Hamilton taxicab license on or before September 10,
1992 shall be exempt from paying the aforesaid nonrefundable application fee.
      (Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.09 PUBLIC HEARING.
   Upon receipt of the initial application or a subsequent application to amend
a certificate of public convenience and necessity, the City Manager, or his
designated representative, shall thereupon set a date for public hearing upon
the application and shall cause a notice of the public hearing to be published
in a newspaper of general circulation in Butler County at least one week prior
to the date of the hearing. The City Manager or his representative shall
investigate the statements contained in the application and determine whether
granting the application will further public convenience and necessity.
   At the hearing, the City Manager, or his designate, shall receive
information and argument as to the need or desirability of allowing another
taxicab business in the City with respect to the public convenience and
necessity from the applicant and from other persons who may appear. From such
information and argument, and from such additional information as may have been
obtained through independent investigation, the City Manager shall determine
whether public convenience and necessity require the issuance of the
certificate applied for.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.10 GRANTING OF CERTIFICATE.
   If the City Manager determines that the applicant has satisfied all the
requirements of this chapter as to requisite financial and business character;
that the same will be in the best interest of public; and that granting the
application will promote public convenience and necessity; the City Manager
shall grant the application and issue a certificate of public convenience and
necessity to the applicant.
   The certificate of public convenience and necessity shall include the
following information:
   (a)   The name of the applicant granted the certificate (the certificate
holder);
   (b)   The number of taxicabs the certificate holder may lawfully operate in
the City;
   (c)   The name under which the certificate holder will conduct business;
   (d)   The principal place of business of the certificate holder;
   (e)   The exclusive color scheme and special terms to be used exclusively by
the certificate holder on its taxicabs;
   (f)   A statement that the certificate is not transferrable without the
approval of the City Manager, and may be revoked or suspended; and
   (g)   A statement that the certificate holder is subject to the rules and
regulations contained herein.
      (Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.11 SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION.
   (a)   Any certificate of public convenience and necessity may be suspended
or revoked at at any time by the City Manager, or his designate, if:
      (1)   The owner fails to operate its taxicab company in accordance with
the provisions of this chapter, or other ordinances of this City, or the laws
of Ohio; or
      (2)   The owner ceases to operate such taxicabs for a period of thirty
consecutive days without first obtaining the consent of the City Manager, or
his designate; or
      (3)   The owner fails to keep in force or on deposit with the City the
policy of insurance hereinafter described; or
      (4)   The owner fails to report to the Director of Finance any
information received from a physician in accordance with Ohio R.C. 2305.33 that
a taxicab driver is or may be unfit to operate a taxicab.
   However, no certificate shall be revoked unless due notice of a hearing is
given to the holder thereof and such hearing has been duly had thereon.
   (b)   In the event of a violation of any of the provisions of in this
chapter which results in an emergency situation in which continued operation by
the taxicab company endangers the health, welfare or safety of the public, or
manifests a conscious disregard for the provisions of this chapter, the City
Manager, or his designate, may suspend any certificate issued hereunder; any
such suspension may be made effective immediately and without a hearing pending
the conduct of a hearing within fifty-eight hours, but provided that no such
hearing shall take place on a Saturday, a Sunday or a legal holiday. In such an
event, a hearing shall take place on the next business day immediately
following the Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday when such hearing would
otherwise have been proper.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.12 CERTIFICATE NOT TRANSFERABLE.
   A certificate of public convenience and necessity issued under this chapter
is not transferable and may not be transferred by way of, but not limited to, a
transfer by sale, lease, assignment, sublease, barter or gift of the
certificate itself, or by a sale, lease, assignment, sublease, barter or gift
of the assets or stock of an entity which holds a certificate unless and until
written approval is obtained from the City Manager. In order to obtain
approval, the transferee shall submit an application to the City Manager and it
shall be treated as an application under Sections 761.08 through 761.11.
   Should a corporation cease doing business, a successor corporation to the
defunct corporation shall secure a new certificate.
   There shall be no right to the transfer of a certificate as such certificate
is issued based on a consideration of the totality of the circumstances at the
time the certificate was issued or last amended.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.13 FRAUDULENT INFORMATION PROHIBITED.
   No person shall give any fictitious information to practice any fraud,
misrepresentation or subterfuge in securing or attempting to secure a
certificate of public convenience and necessity provided for in this chapter.
Should fraud, misrepresentation or subterfuge be engaged in as a part of
securing or attempting to secure a certificate, any certificate issued based,
in whole or in part, upon such activity shall be void.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.14 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No person, owner or taxicab company, either's heirs, successors or assigns,
either's lessees, trustees, receivers or trustees appointed by any court
whatsoever, shall operate any taxicab for the transportation of persons for
hire on any street within the corporate limits of the City, except in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.15 CERTIFICATE REQUIRED; COMPANY CONDITIONS.
   No person, owner or taxicab company shall operate any taxicab for the
transportation of persons or property over any of the streets of the City when:
   (a)   The contract of hire is entered into within the corporation limits of
the City, or
   (b)   When the point of embarkation is within the City, unless such company
has obtained a certificate of public convenience and necessity for such
operation pursuant to the provisions of this chapter.
      (Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.16 USE OF UNLICENSED DRIVERS PROHIBITED.
   No person, owner, taxicab company, operator or driver shall permit any
taxicab belonging to or under control of such person, owner, taxicab company,
operator or driver to be driven for hire by any person who is not a licensed
taxicab driver under the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.17 USE OF UNLICENSED TAXICABS PROHIBITED.
   No person, owner, taxicab company or operator shall permit the operation of,
nor shall any driver operate, an unlicensed taxicab for purposes of conveying
passengers or property to any destination from a point of embarkation within
the City.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.18 BOND OR LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIRED.
   No owner, operator or taxicab company, either's heirs, successors or
assigns, either's lessees, trustees, receivers or court-appointed trustees
shall operate a public hack, taxicab or other vehicle kept for hire, or permit
the same to be operated, nor shall any certificate of public convenience and
necessity be granted, unless and until the applicant for that privilege
deposits with the City Manager in a form approved by the Director of Finance
and the Director of Law:
   (a)   A policy or certificate of liability insurance covering both
passengers and third parties, for each taxicab for which a license is issued,
by an insurance company licensed and admitted in the State, which policy shall
"pay on behalf of" the insured:
      (1)   Liability insurance with limits of one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000) per person bodily injury and property damage per occurrence;
      (2)   Covering all taxicabs operated by applicant;
      (3)   Providing uninsured and underinsured motorist coverage of not less
than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000) per person;
      (4)   Deleting any exclusions or limitations or exceptions as follows:
when the vehicle is being used as a public livery or conveyance;
      (5)   The policy or certificate shall further contain a warranty by the
insurance company that in the event of any cancellation, non-renewal or
material change in the terms and conditions of such policy, the City Manager
shall be given at least ten days of advance notice of same.
   (b)   The liability insurance required pursuant to subsection (a) hereof may
contain a deductible in an amount not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000).
   (c)   Each taxicab company shall provide the City with a bond or cashier's
check for one thousand dollars ($1,000) for the purpose of covering medical
expenses of taxicab passengers injured during the course of the company's
operation and shall maintain such protection.
      (Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.19 RECORDS.
   Every taxicab company shall keep a record of all its taxicabs showing the
body number, the state license license plate number and such other data as may
be necessary to identify the driver of such taxicab at all times, including
hours of employment of each driver, or hours of operation permitted under a
lease between a driver and the holder of a certificate of public convenience
and necessity.
   All taxicab companies shall maintain daily call sheets or trip records made
by their drivers for each day of operation showing the time of beginning and
the time of ending of each trip, the first and last stop and the amount of fare
collected. Such record shall be subject to inspection at all times by the City
and shall not be destroyed for a period of three years.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.20 INCOME TAX TO BE WITHHELD.
   (a)   Upon the basis of its records set forth in Section
761.19, the holder of a certificate of public convenience and necessity shall
withhold from its employee's wages an amount equal to the amount due the City
as income tax on the amounts earned by such driver and forward same to the City
as required by Chapter 191 of the Administrative code. Should the holder of the
certificate fail to withhold or collect income tax from its employees as
required by this section, the certificate holder shall become and remain liable
for the same in addition to its driver, and its certificate may be revoked or
suspended if taxes owed are not paid when due according to Chapter 191 of the
Administrative Code.
   (b)   A holder of a certificate which conducts its business in such a manner
as to avoid characterization of the drivers of taxicabs its licenses as the
certificate holder's employees shall pay income tax to the City, at the rate
established by Chapter 191 of the Administrative Code, upon the gross lease
price for each taxicab which it leases that has been granted a Hamilton taxicab
license. Should the holder of a certificate fail to pay the tax imposed by this
section, its certificate may be suspended or revoked.
   (c)   Every taxicab driver who operates a taxicab within the City under a
lease with a holder of a certificate in order to avoid having the driver
characterized as an employee of the holder of the certificate shall withhold
and pay to the City the appropriate income tax in such amount and upon such
terms as are required by Chapter 191 of the Administrative Code. Should the
taxicab driver fail to pay the tax imposed by this section or pay the tax
imposed when due, the driver's taxicab operator's license may be suspended or
revoked.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.21 COLOR SCHEME AND INSIGNIA REQUIRED.
   (a)   No taxicab company covered by the provisions of this chapter shall be
authorized or permitted to use a color scheme, name, monogram or insignia that
in the opinion of the City Manager imitates a color scheme, monogram, name or
insignia used by any other taxicab company, or act in such fashion as to
mislead or tend to deceive the public. In case of dispute as to the right to
use any name, insignia, monogram, color scheme or style of painting or
lettering, it shall be resolved in favor of the person having the earlier
priority of use, unless he has abandoned such use for one year or more.
   (b)   After a certificate of public convenience and necessity has been
issued to a taxicab company, the color scheme, monogram or insignia of the
company's taxicab shall not be changed without the prior written approval of
the City Manager, or his designate and amendment of its certification of public
convenience and necessity.
   (c)   The full name, monogram or insignia of the taxicab company shall be
conspicuously displayed on each side and rear of each taxicab, in letters at
least three inches high or, in the case of a monogram or insignia, not less
than eight inches high.
   (d)   Prior to the issuance of a certificate, the applicant shall present a
photograph to the City Manager in the color of the color scheme, name, monogram
or insignia it intends to use.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.22 IDENTIFICATION RESTRICTION.
   No person owning or operating any taxicab, having adopted any distinctive
name, design, color scheme or style of painting or lettering, shall operate any
taxicab not prominently bearing such name, design, color scheme or style of
painting or lettering. Taxicabs not properly marked shall not be put into
service. Any improperly marked vehicle nevertheless placed in service shall be
removed from service until it is properly marked.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.23 TAXICAB SERVICE TO BE CONTINUOUS.
   All taxicab companies shall:
   (a)   Provide taxicab service on a twenty-four hour a day, seven days a week
basis;
   (b)   Maintain a business office within the local telephone service exchange
which shall be kept open at all times to receive calls and dispatch taxicabs;
   (c)   Respond to all requests for service as soon as possible, and in the
event that service cannot be furnished within a reasonable time if the taxicab
company is provided with a phone number, the operator shall inform the
prospective passenger of the reason for the delay and how long it will be
before the service can be furnished; and
   (d)   Accept requests for service anywhere within the City when taxicabs are
available for such service; failure or refusal, except for conditions beyond
the control of the operator, to furnish continuous service, shall be deemed a
violation of this section, and the certificate of public convenience and
necessity may be suspended or revoked pursuant to the provisions of this
chapter.
      (Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.24 APPLICATION FOR A LICENSE TO OPERATE ONE OR MORE TAXICABS.
   The holder of a certificate of public convenience and necessity issued
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall apply to the Director of
Finance for a license to operate such number of taxicabs belonging to the
certificate holder as may come within the scope of its certificate. Such
application shall be in writing and shall state the full name and address of
the holder of the certificate as applicant, the trade name under which the
applicant is authorized to do business according to its certificate, the type
of vehicle and a current photograph of the vehicle for which the license is
desired, the length of time such vehicle has been in use and its odometer
reading, the number of persons it is capable of carrying and, the design, color
scheme, the local symbol used or proposed to be used, together with all other
lettering or marks used or proposed to be used by the applicant on the vehicle.
   The City Manager or his designee may require such additional information as
to the financial responsibility and fitness of management, of officers and of
stockholders of the applicant, and such other information about the applicant
or the application as he may desire. The application, together with any
statements or further information required by the City Manager or his designee
shall have affixed thereto an affidavit duly sworn by the applicant respecting
the accuracy of the requirements set forth above.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.25 INSPECTION.
   (a)   No vehicle covered by the terms of this chapter shall be licensed
until it has been:
      (1)   Inspected and examined for safety by an ASA or ASE certified
mechanic or agency selected by the City Manager, and certified as having passed
the inspection;
         (Ord. 96-2-21. Passed 2-28-96.)
      (2)   The taximeter has been tested by the Transportation and Traffic
Division or Butler County Auditor, and found to be accurate within two percent
(2%) and to correctly indicate the amount of fare to be charged as provided by
this chapter; and
      (3)   Inspected, examined and passed inspection for compliance with this
chapter by the Transportation and Traffic Division.
         (Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   (b)   The Transportation and Traffic Division may and is hereby authorized
to establish reasonable standards for taxicab inspections which may include,
but are not limited to:
      (1)   Establishing and conducting a program of annual service and
maintenance of such taxicabs and providing proof of compliance;
      (2)   Inspection of the taxicab for dangerous structural or mechanical
conditions which may cause harm to the occupants;
      (3)   The inclusion of approved seatbelts for the total number of
occupants of such taxicabs; and
      (4)   Compliance with the requirements of this chapter.
   Inspections under this subsection shall be performed by an ASA or ASE
mechanic or an employee of the Transportation and Traffic Division.
(Ord. 96-2-21. Passed 2-28-96.)
   761.26 ISSUANCE OF LICENSE TO OPERATE.
   If the City Manager or his designate finds that the applicant for a license
to operate a taxicab has been issued a certificate of public convenience and
necessity; that the applicant has not met or exceeded the number of taxicabs it
may operate according to the applicant's certificate of public convenience and
necessity, and that the proposed taxicab meets or exceeds the standards
promulgated by the Transportation and Traffic Division, the Director of Finance
shall issue to the certificate holder a license to operate such taxicab upon
showing proof of the insurance policy heretofore described and paying the
license fee hereinafter set forth. There shall be delivered to such certificate
holder a license which shall contain the vehicle identification and license
number of the licensed taxicab, the name and address of the certificate holder
and such other information as the Director prescribes. A copy of the license
shall be affixed to the interior of the taxicab so licensed so as to be readily
accessible and visible to anyone desiring to examine the same. Any license
issued hereunder shall expire on December 31 of the year in which it was
issued, unless sooner suspended or revoked for cause.
   Every certificate holder hereunder shall pay a fee of ten dollars ($10.00)
per year for each taxicab licensed to operate up to a maximum of two hundred
dollars ($200.00). The fee for issuing any such license after July 1 in any
year shall be fifty percent (50%) of that specified above. (Ord. 96-2-21.
Passed 2-28-96.)
   761.27 SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF TAXICAB LICENSE.
   Any license to operate a taxicab may be suspended or revoked at any time by
the City Manager or his designate, regardless of any criminal proceedings, if:
   (a)   The owner's application for license contained a material false
statement; or
   (b)   The owner fails to operate the licensed taxicab in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter and other ordinances of the City and the laws of
Ohio; or
   (c)   The owner ceases to operate such taxicab for a period of thirty
consecutive days without first obtaining the consent of the City Manager or his
designate; or
   (d)   The owner fails to keep in force or on deposit with the City policy or
insurance certificate hereinabove described; or
   (e)   The taxicab has been operated in violation of this chapter.
   A revocation shall take effect only after a hearing. Notice of such hearing
shall be sent to the licensee personally or by leaving a copy at a place of
business designated in the license. A hearing upon the revocation shall occur
within seven days.
   Any taxicab license issued by the City may be suspended by the City Manager
or his designee for a period not to exceed sixty days. Any such suspension
shall be put into effect by serving a notice thereof upon the certificate
holder by leaving a copy at his place of business as designated in the license.
Such notice shall specify the reason for the suspension and the period of time,
in no case exceeding thirty days, within which the condition causing the
suspension must be corrected and may state that unless such correction is made
within such time, the license will be revoked.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.28 LICENSE TRANSFER; FEE; SUBSTITUTING EQUIPMENT.
   Taxicab licenses may not be transferred from one certificate holder to
another or to any person not already holding a certificate of public
convenience and necessity, but upon application duly filed, a taxicab license
may be transferred to other equipment owned by the same certificate holder upon
payment of a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and surrender of the prior
license. Applications for transfer shall be referred to the Transportation and
Traffic Division for investigation in the same manner as required in the case
of an original application for a license, and such license may thereafter be
transferred to cover the substituted equipment upon finding that the proposed
substituted equipment is safe and that it complies with all requirements of the
chapter and all ordinances of the City. A transferred license shall expire on
the same date as the license it replaces.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.29 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   A license is hereby required for every taxicab operated in the City. No
person shall operate a vehicle as a taxicab for the purpose of carrying
passengers or property on trips beginning in the City without a license.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.30 LICENSING COMPLIANCE.
   No person shall engage in the business of operating one or more taxicabs
without paying the annual license fee required by this chapter and no person
shall fail to comply with all the provisions of this chapter and all ordinances
pertaining to the regulation of taxicabs.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.31 REGULATION OF TAXICABS.
   (a)   A taxicab, if a sedan, shall have at least four doors and, if a van,
shall have at least three doors, sufficient room and a seatbelt for each
passenger it carries and provide for ease of passenger entry and exit.
   (b)   Each taxicab shall carry an operable fire extinguisher, a first aid
kit and operable emergency reflective signs which shall be used in case of
breakdown.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   (c)   Each taxicab shall be inspected biannually by an ASA or ASE certified
mechanic and shall present proof, upon request, that it has successfully passed
the inspection.
(Ord. 96-2-21. Passed 2-28-96.)
   (d)   Each taxicab shall have posted, in a place and in print size that is
easily visible to passengers, a schedule of rates charged by the taxicab
company, which shall not exceed those authorized by this chapter.
   (e)   Each taxicab shall have the name of the taxicab company painted on the
side in letters of sufficient size so as to be clearly visible.
   (f)   Each taxicab shall prominently display a copy of the license issued
under this chapter in the interior of the vehicle.
   (g)   Each taxicab shall have a light within the passenger compartment,
capable of being lighted or extinguished upon the request of the passenger.
   (h)   Each taxicab shall have brakes sufficient to stop the taxicab during
normal weather conditions in a safe and reasonable fashion and stopping
distance.
   (i)   Each taxicab shall have safety seat belts for each passenger and the
driver: at least two in the rear seat and one for the front passenger and one
for the driver's seat.
   (j)   All taxicab owners or operators and taxicab drivers shall maintain
their equipment in good mechanical condition at all times and shall not operate
any vehicle with a defect that would tend to affect the safe operation of such
vehicle, or the safety of others on the road. (Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   (k)   Each taxicab not operating on a flat fare rate shall be equipped with
a lighted sign atop the exterior of the vehicle which shall be visible after
dark from a distance of fifty feet and which shall illuminate the word "Taxi",
"Cab" or "Taxicab" to indicate the vehicle is in operation and subject to call.
(Ord. 96-2-21. Passed 2-28-96.)
   761.32 FRAUDULENT INFORMATION PROHIBITED.
   No person shall give any fictitious information or practice any fraud,
misrepresentation or subterfuge in securing or attempting to secure a license
to operate a taxicab provided for in this chapter.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.33 SURRENDER OF LICENSE CERTIFICATE; DESTRUCTION OF LICENSE.
   No person whose license has been suspended or revoked shall fail, refuse or
neglect to surrender the license certificate, nor shall any person conceal or
destroy any license certificate during the year for which such license was
issued.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.34 OPERATING A TAXICAB DURING LICENSE SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION.
   No person shall operate any taxicab during any period in which the license
therefor is suspended or revoked.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.35 TAXIMETERS REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person shall operate or permit to be operated in the City any
taxicab on a distance tariff, or transport passengers in or offer a taxicab for
hire, unless such vehicle is equipped with a taximeter that has been approved
for accuracy by the Transportation and Traffic Engineer or Butler County
Auditor.
   (b)   No person shall operate or drive a taxicab unless a taximeter is used
in determining the fare to be charged, and no greater fare shall be charged
than what is recorded on the reading face of such taximeter for the trip,
except that the hourly rate may be used by previous arrangement with the
passengers after the meter has registered an amount equal to that of the first
hour, conforming to the rates as herein provided for. No other methods of
figuring rates or measuring distances shall be allowed.
   (c)   No person shall operate or drive a taxicab after sundown without
having the face of the taximeter thereon illuminated as hereinafter provided,
or drive a taxicab without having the taximeter set and regulated to conform
with the rates of fare in this chapter.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.36 CONDITION OF TAXIMETER.
   No person shall operate any taxicab if any part of the mechanism of or in
connection with the taximeter has been changed, altered or disconnected since
it was last tested by the City, or if the City test seal or such taximeter is
broken, removed or defaced, or if upon test or inspection the taximeter is
found to register inaccurately until such taximeter is tested and found to
register accurately.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.37 TESTING OF TAXIMETER.
   The Transportation and Traffic Division shall inspect and test the taximeter
or every taxicab as follows:
   (a)   At least every six months while in service;
   (b)   Whenever the schedule of rates is changed;
   (c)   Whenever the previous test seal is broken, removed or defaced, if the
taximeter is to be continued in service;
   (d)   Whenever the taximeter or any mechanism of or in connection with it
has been removed, disconnected, broken or repaired, and it is to be restored to
service; and
   (e)   Whenever any credible complaint is made to the Transportation and
Traffic Division or to a law enforcement officer that any taximeter is not
registering accurately.
      (Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.38 TAXIMETER TEST AND INSPECTION FEE.
   The owner of a taxicab shall pay to the Department of Finance a fee of
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for every test or inspection of a taximeter,
except for tests made upon complaint of another individual when the taximeter
is found to register correctly, and except for inspection not resulting in a
finding of inaccuracy, made upon the request of the Transportation and Traffic
Division more than once in six months.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.39 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   (a)   Every person desiring to drive a taxicab shall submit an application
for a taxicab driver's license to the Director of Finance on a form provided
for that purpose. The applicant shall answer all questions in the application.
An application for a taxicab driver's license shall be verified under oath and
shall contain the following information:
      (1)   The names and addresses of four persons, excluding other taxicab
drivers, owners and operators, who have known the applicant for a period of
three years and who will attest to the sobriety, honesty and general good
character of the applicant;
      (2)   The experience of the applicant in the transportation of
passengers;
      (3)   The educational background of the applicant;
      (4)   A concise history of the applicant's employment;
      (5)   Disclosure of whether the applicant is currently licensed to drive
a taxicab in any other locale and identify such locale; and
      (6)   Identification of all the applicant's places of residence for the
past three years.
   At the time the application is filed, the applicant shall pay the Director
of Finance an application fee of seventeen dollars ($17.00).
   (b)   Upon receipt of the application, the Transportation and Traffic
Division shall cause to be made such investigation of the applicant as is
necessary to determine whether the applicant meets the requirements set forth
in this chapter. Such investigation may include a written or oral examination
designed to test the applicant's knowledge of locations and landmarks within
the City.
   (c)   The Police Division shall arrange with the Bureau of Criminal
Identification for a background investigation of each applicant for a taxicab
driver's license at the applicant's expense. A report of such investigation and
a copy of the applicant's traffic conviction record, of any, obtained at the
applicant's expense from the Ohio Bureau of Motor Vehicles pursuant to Ohio
R.C. 4509.05, shall be attached to the application for consideration.
   (d)   When a person desiring a taxicab driver's license has submitted to the
City a completed application; paid the application fee; successfully passed an
examination of the applicant's knowledge of the City's locations and landmarks;
provided a drug screening which does not disclose the presence of drugs being
tested for; and has provided the Director of Finance with a Bureau of Criminal
Identification background investigation as well as a traffic conviction record
from the Ohio Bureau of Motor Vehicles; the applicant shall be granted a
temporary taxicab driver's license for a period not to exceed seven calendar
days provided the application forms and required attachments do not immediately
reveal on their face the existence of facts or circumstances which would
warrant denial of a license or the revocation or suspension of a previously
issued license.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.40 REQUIREMENTS FOR TAXICAB DRIVER'S LICENSE.
   (a)   An applicant for the initial issuance or subsequent renewal of a
taxicab driver's license shall meet the following requirements:
      (1)   Be twenty or more years of age;
      (2)   Be in sound physical condition, have good eyesight and not subject
to any infirmity, defect or disorder of mind or body which might reasonably
render him/her unfit for the safe carrying out of the duties of driving a
taxicab, as determined from all reliable medical, psychological or health
information supplied by the driver or other persons concerning the driver's
physical or mental condition and a drug test as set forth in Section
761.41. The qualifications in this subsection shall be supported by an
affidavit of the applicant.
      (3)   Possess a working knowledge of the traffic laws of the City of
Hamilton and the state of Ohio; and
      (4)   Possess a valid operator's license issued by the State.
   (b)   A taxicab driver's license may not be issued to any person who:
      (1)   Has been convicted of, pled guilty or no contest to, any offense
constituting a felony within the previous five years;
      (2)   Has been adjudged mentally incompetent and has not been legally
restored to competency;
      (3)   Is awaiting court action for any criminal offense;
      (4)   Is subject to any infirmity, defect or disorder of mind or body
which might reasonably render him/her unfit for the safe carrying out of the
duties of a taxicab driver, or a taxicab operator as determined from all
reliable medical, psychological or health information supplied by the applicant
or other persons concerning the applicant's physical or mental condition;
      (5)   Within two years prior to filing the application for a license has
been convicted of, pled guilty to or forfeited bond for four or more moving
traffic offenses, whether charged under State law or ordinances of any
jurisdiction;
      (6)   Has complied an unsafe driving record based on a consideration of
the applicant's driving prior to the previous three years; or a persistent
record of arrests or convictions that exhibit a disregard for the law;
      (7)   Has had his or her driver's license suspended by a court within
three years preceding the application;
      (8)   Has had his or her driver's license suspended by administrative
action within three years preceding the application;
      (9)   Has been convicted within three years preceding the application of
either driving or being in physical control of a motor vehicle while under the
influence of alcohol and/or drugs, driving while under suspension or reckless
operation, drag racing, leaving the scene of an accident or substantially
similar offenses as defined and prohibited by the laws of Ohio, any other state
or any municipality irrespective of the state in which it is located; or
      (10)   When tested for the use of drugs of abuse, tests positively for
such use and cannot provide a medical justification or another good and legal
reason for such positive test result.
         (Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.41 TAXICAB DRIVER/APPLICANT DRUG TESTING.
   (a)   Definitions. As used in this chapter, the following terms are defined
as follows:
      (1)   "Drug test" means a urinalysis test administered under approved
conditions and procedures to detect any of the following: amphetamines,
barbiturates, benzodiazephines (valium, librium), bensolylecongnine (cocaine
metabolite), cannabinoids (THC, Marihuana), opiates (codeine), morphine (from
heroin), dydromorphone, methaqualone, methadone and phyencyclidine (PCP);
      (2)   "Reasonable suspicion" means an apparent state of facts,
circumstances or information which exists from an inquiry or from a creditable
source which would induce a reasonably intelligent and prudent person to
believe the taxicab driver was under the influence or using drugs/narcotics;
and
      (3)   "Narcotic drugs" mean coca leaves, opium, isonipecaine, amidone,
isoamidone, ketobemidone, as defined herein, and every substance not chemically
distinguished from them and every drug, other than cannabis, which may be
included in the meaning of "narcotic drug" under the federal drug abuse control
laws. "Coca leaves" includes cocaine and any compound, manufacture, salt,
derivative, mixture or preparation of coca leaves, except derivatives of coca
leaves, which do not contain cocaine, ecogine or substances for which cocaine
or ecogine may be synthesized or made. "Isonipecaine" means any substance
identified chemically as 1-methyl-4-phenylpiperidine-4-carboxylic acid ethyl
ester, or any salt thereof, by whatever trade name designated. "Amidone" means
any substance identified chemically as 4-4-diphenyl-6-dimethylamino-heptanone-
3, or any salt thereof, by whatever trade name designated. "Isoamidone" means
any substance identified chemically as 4-4-diphenyl-5-methyl-6-
dimethylaminohexzone-3, or any salt thereof, by whatever trade name designated.
"Ketobemidone" means any substance identified chemically as 4-(3-
hydroxyphenyl)-1-methyl-4-piperidyl ethyl ketone hydrochloride, or any salt
thereof, by whatever trade name designated.
         (Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   (b)   General Rules.
      (1)   Taxicab drivers shall not take any narcotic or controlled substance
unless prescribed by a physician licensed to practice medicine. Drivers who are
required to take prescription medication shall notify their immediate
supervisors of the medication prescribed and the nature of the illness or
injury; any statutorily defined illegal use of drugs by a driver, whether
during or outside employment, which results in a positive drug test indicating
the presence of substances being tested for at or above the designated level,
shall be grounds to deny, suspend or revoke a taxicab driver's license. Refusal
by a person to take a drug test required by this section, reveal its results or
follow the regulations prescribed in this section, shall also constitute
grounds for denial, suspension or revocation of a taxicab driver's license.
      (2)   Applicants or drivers found to be involved in the illegal sale,
manufacture or distribution of any narcotic/drug shall be denied a taxicab
driver's license.
      (3)   Applicants or drivers who are found to be illegal using any
controlled substance shall be subject to disciplinary action.
      (4)   Applicants or drivers demonstrating addiction to any narcotic/drug
shall be denied a license.
      (5)   Any improper use of any narcotic/drug by an applicant after
application, but before issuance of a taxicab license, shall be grounds for
denying a license.
      (6)   Any person providing a drug sample pursuant to this section shall
execute a waiver of physician-patient privilege respecting all aspects of the
drug test and its results.
      (7)   A taxicab company shall submit to the City the original copy of the
results of any drug test it received or that it conducts upon a driver or
applicant.
   (c)   Policy for Drug Testing/Urinalysis.
      (1)   All applicants for a taxicab driver's license shall be tested for
drug or narcotic usage as part of the prelicensing process. The results of such
test shall be reported directly from the testing agency to the Director of
Finance.
         (Ord. 93-3-20. Passed 3-10-93.)
      (2)   Current taxicab drivers shall be required to submit to a test for
drug or narcotic usage as outlined below:
         A.   A drug test may be ordered by a law enforcement officer or other
City official having enforcement responsibility under this chapter when there
is a reasonable suspicion that a driver has been using any drug or narcotic and
that this use may present a risk to his or her safety, that of fellow
employees, other motorists or the public.
         B.   A drug test may be ordered on a random and unannounced basis by
the Transportation and Traffic Engineer without regard to reasonable suspicion.
         C.   The purpose of either test is to determine if any drug or
narcotic is present in the driver's system and the extent or amount of such
presence. The driver shall be advised of the content and details of any such
finding.
         D.   Any official who orders a drug test based upon a reasonable
suspicion of the use of any drug or narcotic shall forward a report containing
the facts and circumstances directly to the driver and the Director of Finance.
The driver shall be verbally advised of the reasonable suspicion at the time of
the test and receive a written statement of the same reasonable suspicion
within twenty-four hours of the test.
         E.   Test results reporting a presence of illegal drugs or narcotics
at or above a prohibited level, or the use of prescription drugs without
prescription or the abuse of any over-the-counter drugs shall be submitted to
the taxicab company and the Director of Finance for further action.
      (3)   Every taxicab company, owner or operator shall report to the
Director of Finance any information received from a physician in accordance
with Ohio R.C. 2305.33 that a taxicab driver is or may be unfit to operate a
taxicab.
   (d)   Urinalysis Procedures. The testing procedure and safeguards set forth
in this section should be followed by the examining physician and others
involved in the testing procedure.
      (1)   Obtaining urine samples:
         A.   the driver shall be notified of the drug test requirement just
prior to being transported without delay to the medical facility or laboratory
designated to obtain the urine sample. At the time of the test, the subject
shall be notified of the specific drugs which will be screened by the test. The
driver shall be accompanied by a testing supervisor of the same sex.
         B.   The room where the same is obtained shall be private and secure
with documentation maintained that the area has been searched and is free of
any foreign substance. The testing supervisor, of the same sex, shall be in the
presence of the driver to ensure that the sample is from the driver and when
actually passed at the time noted on the record. Specimen collection shall
occur in a medical setting and the procedures should not demean, embarrass or
cause physical discomfort to the driver.
         C.   Before the testing, the applicant should be advised of the drug
testing and should receive a briefing during which collection and analysis
procedures are explained. An interview with the driver prior to the test shall
serve to establish use of drugs currently taken under medical supervision. The
driver/applicant shall be required to identify any prescription or
nonprescription medication taken in the past week. The medication and time last
taken shall be noted on a form to be designated for this purpose. Medications
containing narcotic drugs, hypnotics, stimulants, depressants, sedatives and
most muscle relaxants shall be reported. Drugs such as aspirin, cold
medications, tylenol, birth control pills and antihistamines, except those
containing codeine, need not be reported. In the event the driver/applicant is
taking medications which require reporting, the testing officer shall attempt
to verify the validity of this use through interviews and request the driver/
applicant to provide a copy of the prescription. The completed form shall
accompany the specimen.
         D.   The containers shall be new and free of contaminants.
         E.   The driver/applicant shall deposit a minimum volume of urine (two
ounces) in each container and tightly cap it. Drivers/applicants who are unable
to provide an adequate sample initially shall remain under observation until
able to do so.
         F.   A tamper-proof seal shall be used on the containers.
         G.   Each step in the collection and processing of the urine sample
shall be documented to establish procedural integrity and the chain of
evidence.
      (2)   Processing urine samples. To ensure optimum accuracy, the test
shall be drug specific. The drug screening test shall consist of an initial
test and, if a positive result is thereby obtained, a confirming test.
         A.   The initial test of each urine sample shall employ a methodology
different from any confirming test.
         B.   The initial screening test shall be the EMIT (Enzyme Multiplied
Immunoassay Technique). The test process at the laboratory for the initial
analysis shall be completed in twenty-four to forty-eight hours. The following
initial cutoff levels shall be used when screening specimens to determine
whether they are negative for these five drugs or classes of drugs:
 
                      Initial Test Cutoff
                      Levels (ng/ml)
Marijuana metabolites 100
Cocaine metabolite    300
Opiate metabolites    *300
Phyencyclidine        25
Amphetamines          1,000
   *25 ng/ml if immunoassay specific for free morphine
         C.   All specimens identified as positive on the initial test shall be
confirmed using gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GC/MS) techniques at the
cutoff levels listed in this paragraph for each drug. All confirmations shall
be by quantitative analysis. Concentrations that exceed the linear region of
the standard curve shall be documented in the laboratory record as "greater
than highest standard curve value."
                        Confirmatory Test
                        Cutoff Levels (ng/mg)
Marijuana metabolites 1 15
Cocaine metabolite 2    150
Opiates:
Morphine                300
Codeine                 300
Phencyclidine           25
Amphetamines:
Amphetamine             500
Methamphetamine         500
   1 Delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol-9-carboxylic acid.
   2 Benzoylecgonine.
         D.   The laboratory shall report as negative all specimens that are
negative on the initial test or negative on the confirmatory test. Only
specimens confirmed positive shall be reported positive for a specific drug.
         E.   The testing laboratory shall make provisions to properly preserve
(for sixty days), store and secure a testable portion of the original urine
specimen to be preserved and made available for purposes of independent
confirmation testing by experts chosen and authorized by the driver/applicant.
This confirmation test shall be conducted at the testing laboratory jointly
with the experts representing the driver/applicant and at the driver/
applicant's expense.
      (3)   All persons receiving a positive test result for substances
identified in subsection (a)(1) hereof, shall be subject to being denied a
license or having any previously issued license suspended or revoked.
         (Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.42 LICENSE ISSUANCE; EXPIRATION AND RENEWAL.
   (a)   Upon approval of the application, the Director of Finance shall upon
payment of a seven-dollar ($7.00) license fee, issue a license to the applicant
authorizing that person to drive a taxicab.
   (b)   All taxicab driver's licenses shall expire annually on December 31
unless sooner revoked.
   (c)   All applications for renewal of licenses shall be filed with the
Director within one month of the date of expiration of each year, and renewal
licenses shall be issued in the same manner and upon the same conditions as
prescribed herein for initial licenses.
   (d)   If a license is denied or renewal is refused, the Director shall cause
written notification of such denial or refusal to be given to the applicant by
regular mail at the address stated in the application, and such written
notification shall include the basis for such denial or refusal. A denial or
refusal may be appealed and a hearing before the Director or his/her designate
thereon shall be held within seven days.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.43 LICENSE SUSPENSION/REVOCATION.
   (a)   The City Manager or his designate shall have the right and authority
to suspend or revoke any taxicab driver's license whenever just cause exists.
Just cause includes, but is not limited to, the following:
      (1)   The licensee has violated any of the provisions of this chapter;
      (2)   The licensee's physical or mental condition is such as to render
him/her unfit for the safe carrying out of the duties of a taxicab driver;
      (3)   The licensee voluntarily transport any person knowing or having
reasonable cause to believe such person was at the time of such transportation
engaged in any illegal activity;
      (4)   The licensee has intentionally given false answers to any questions
on his/her application for such license, or in connection with the operation of
a taxicab;
      (5)   The licensee permits a taxicab to be operated for hire by a person
not licensed as a taxicab driver by the City;
      (6)   The licensee has compiled an unsafe driving record, or a record of
arrests that exhibits a disregard of the law;
      (7)   The licensee fails to maintain all the general qualifications
applicable to the initial issuance of a license;
      (8)   The licensee has been convicted of, pled guilty to or forfeited
bond for any of the following offenses while licensed to operate a taxicab:
         A.   Driving while under the influence of alcohol or any drug of
abuse, or the combined influence of alcohol and any drug of abuse;
         B.   Violation of the Ohio driver's license laws;
         C.   Vehicular homicide;
         D.   Fleeing and eluding a police officer;
         E.   Drag racing;
         F.   Reckless operation;
         G.   Leaving the scene of an accident;
         H.   Any offense constituting a felony;
      (9)   The licensee has failed to create or maintain records of the
operation of a taxicab as required by this chapter or has created or maintained
inaccurate or incomplete records of the operation of a taxicab.
   (b)   After revocation of a taxicab driver's license or taxicab operator's
license hereunder, no application for the same type of license shall be
accepted or considered for a period of twelve months from the date of
revocation.
   (c)   A taxicab driver's license shall be deemed to be suspended or revoked
upon the suspension, revocation or expiration of the licensee's Ohio operator's
or commercial driver's license, and during the term of such suspension,
revocation or expiration.
   (d)   In the event of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter
which results in any emergency situation in which continued operation by the
taxicab driver endangers the health, welfare or safety of the public or which
demonstrates a conscious disregard for the rules and regulations set forth in
this chapter, the City Manager or his designate may suspend any taxicab
driver's license. Any such suspension may be made effective immediately and
shall remain in effect until a full hearing is held before the City Manager or
his designate or is waived.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.44 TAXICAB DRIVER'S LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   No taxicab subject to regulation under this chapter shall be operated
by a driver without first having procured a license for such a purpose from the
City.
   (b)   The taxicab company shall maintain a file on each driver engaged in
transporting persons from points inside the City, showing compliance with
subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.45 DUTIES OF TAXICAB DRIVERS.
   A driver while driving a taxicab shall:
   (a)   Not take any narcotics or dangerous substances unless prescribed by a
person licensed to practice medicine;
   (b)   Not refuse or neglect to convey any person or persons unless
previously engaged or unable or forbidden by the provisions of this chapter to
do so, but the driver may demand the payment of the legal rate of fare in
advance, and may refuse employment unless so prepaid;
   (c)   Not carry any other person other than the passengers first employing
the taxicab, without the express consent of the passenger;
   (d)   Reasonably search the interior of the taxicab after termination of
each trip for any articles left therein; or fail, neglect or refuse to turn in
to the Division of Police within twenty-four hours all articles found in the
taxicab.
   (e)   Report all accidents to the employer and the Transportation and
Traffic Division for purposes of maintaining a safe taxicab fleet and public
safety;
   (f)   Report any change of address to the Transportation and traffic
Division within forty-eight hours;
   (g)   Answer promptly all communications and summons received from the City
respecting the provisions of this chapter and furnish, when requested, detailed
information as to any person transported by the driver.
   (h)   Not operate a taxicab while under the influence of intoxicating liquor
or drugs;
   (i)   Not permit his taxicab to be used for any immoral or illegal purpose
which purpose would be apparent to a reasonably attentive vehicle operator;
   (j)   Proceed with his passenger to his destination by the shortest possible
route;
   (k)   Give a receipt of fare when requested;
   (l)   Possess and display a Hamilton taxicab driver's license while
operating a taxicab under conditions governed by this chapter;
   (m)   Obey all traffic rules established by the laws of Ohio and the City;
   (n)   Obey all rules and regulations governing the operation of taxicabs in
the City;
   (o)   Not permit any person other than his passenger or a trainee to occupy
his taxicab;
   (p)   Not travel about or cruise the streets of the City in search of
passengers; nor solicit passengers while traveling over the streets of the
City; and
   (q)   Not cause his/her taxicab to remain parked and delay the transporting
of the passenger or passengers occupying the taxicab to their destination for a
period in excess of two minutes after the passenger or passengers have entered
the taxicab.
   The purpose of this section is to delineate examples of activity for which
disciplinary action may be taken.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.46 REGULATIONS AND PROHIBITIONS FOR TAXICAB DRIVERS.
   No driver shall:
   (a)   Drive any taxicab while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or
controlled substances, or drink any intoxicating liquor or consume controlled
substances whatsoever while transporting passengers;
   (b)   Charge in excess of the rates fixed;
   (c)   Operate a taxicab unless he has an Ohio driver's license in full force
and effect;
   (d)   Permit another driver to use his identification card;
   (e)   Have on his/her person or ready at hand in the taxicab passenger
compartment any intoxicating liquors or concealed weapons;
   (f)   convey for another any intoxicating liquors;
   (g)   Knowingly solicit or accept passengers engaged in or about to engage
in any immoral or unlawful activity;
   (h)   Deceive or attempt to deceive any passenger, prospective passenger or
other person by any misrepresentation as to the number, ownership or other
information regarding his/her taxicab;
   (i)   Coerce or attempt to coerce any person for the purpose of securing or
attempting to secure the person as a passenger in such taxicabs;
   (j)   Use any fighting words or other language likely to provoke a breach of
the peace;
   (k)   Be the cause of or engage in any quarreling, fighting or other
unlawful acts;
   (l)   Accept passengers who have requested service from another taxicab
operator;
   (m)   Take any route other than the most direct route to a passenger's
destination unless otherwise authorized or directed by the passenger; or
   (n)   Carry in a taxicab more passengers than the seating capacity of the
vehicle, exclusive of the driving seat, as stated in the license application
for such vehicle.
   Any taxicab driver issued a permit hereunder may have such permit suspended
by the municipal judge at any time for any reason deemed necessary by the
municipal judge for the health, welfare and safety of the public and the
residents of the City.
   The purpose of this section is to delineate a non-exhaustive list of
criminal acts by taxicab drivers.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.47 RECORDS.
   The taxicab driver shall keep a record of his or her hours of employment as
a taxicab driver, and shall keep an accurate daily call sheet or trip record
containing a complete record of the operation of each taxicab driven by him/her
each day and the fare charged, and turn this call sheet or trip record over to
the taxicab operator at the end of his/her tour of duty.
   All taxicab drivers shall make records, a copy of which shall be preserved
by the operators, showing time of beginning and the time of ending of each
trip, the first and last stop and the amount of fare collected. Such record
shall be subject to inspection at all times by the City and shall not be
destroyed for a period of one year.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.48 SECURING OR RENEWING TAXICAB DRIVER'S LICENSE; FRAUDULENT INFORMATION
PROHIBITED.
   No person shall give any fictitious information or practice any fraud,
misrepresentation or subterfuge in securing or attempting to secure an original
or renewal taxicab driver's license as provided for in this chapter. Should
fraud, misrepresentation or subterfuge be engaged in as a part of securing any
license issued based, in whole or in part, upon such fraudulent information,
such license shall be void.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.49 DISPLAY OF LICENSE UPON REQUEST OF LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER.
   No person driving a taxicab which is licensed under this chapter shall fail
to produce a taxicab driver's license upon the request of any law enforcement
officer. Failure to produce such a license upon request shall constitute prima
facie evidence of the fact that such person does not possess such a license.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.50 PERIODIC SAFETY AND EQUIPMENT INSPECTIONS.
   (a)   Upon the direction of the Transportation and Traffic Engineer or his
designate, which direction shall occur not less than twice a year and may be
given without warning, a taxicab owner/operator shall immediately present one
or all of his/her/its taxicabs, as the Transportation and Traffic Engineer or
his designate shall require, to the Ohio State Highway Patrol Post on Hamilton-
Middletown Road or such other law enforcement agency as the Transportation and
Traffic Engineer or his designate may direct for a safety and equipment
inspection in accordance with the standards applied by the Ohio State Highway
Patrol.
   (b)   Any taxicab which fails inspection shall immediately be removed from
service and its license shall be suspended. Such taxicab shall not be returned
to service nor have its license restored until such time as:
      (1)   All conditions which caused the taxicab to fail the inspection have
been corrected and have been reinspected,
      (2)   The inspecting agency finds the taxicab passes the same inspection
that it originally failed and provides written verification or a sticker or
that effect, and
      (3)   The taxicab is deemed by the Transportation and Traffic Engineer to
be in full compliance with all applicable rules and regulations contained in
this chapter.
   (c)   If within twenty-four hours of being directed by the Transportation
and Traffic Engineer or his designate to the Ohio State Highway Patrol or other
law enforcement agency for an inspection the taxicab owner/operator does not
present proof that it passed the safety and equipment inspection, or show good
cause because of difficulties originating with the law enforcement agency why
the taxicab could not be inspected within twenty-four hours, the uninspected
taxicab's license shall immediately be suspended and not be restored unless and
until such time as the taxicab passes the safety and equipment inspection.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
   761.51 GASOLINE SURCHARGE FEES.
   In addition to the charges imposed by this chapter, the following gasoline
surcharge fees are hereby established:
   (a)   For fares within the corporate limits of the City of Hamilton, Ohio,
fifty cents ($.50) shall be added to the charge;
   (b)   For fares to or from the City of Fairfield, Ohio, seventy-five cents
($.75) shall be added to the charge;
   (c)   For fares to or from Westchester Township, Ohio, Fairfield Township,
Ohio, the City of Oxford, Ohio, or the City of Middletown, Ohio, one dollar
($1.00) shall be added to the charge;
   (d)   For fares to or from the City of Cincinnati, Ohio, two dollars ($2.00)
shall be added to the charge;
   (e)   For fares to or from the Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International
Airport in Kentucky, or any other location within the Northern Kentucky
(Kenton, Campbell or Boone Counties), three dollars ($3.00) shall be added to
the charge;
   (f)   For fares to or from the Dayton International Airport in Dayton, Ohio,
or any other location within the City of Dayton, Ohio, four dollars ($4.00)
shall be added to the charge;
   (g)   For fares to or from the cities of Columbus, Ohio, Indianapolis,
Indiana, Lexington, Kentucky, or Louisville, Kentucky, eight dollars ($8.00)
shall be added to the charge.
   Each taxicab shall have posted, in a place and in print size that is easily
visible to passengers, a schedule of the gasoline surcharge fees charged by the
taxicab company, as set forth in subsections (a) through (g) above, which fees
shall not exceed those authorized by this chapter.
(Ord. 2005-9-96. Passed 9-28-05.)
   761.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be punished as defined in Section
501.99 of the General Offenses code.
(Ord. 92-8-66. Passed 8-12-92.)
