   901.01 ENCROACHMENTS ON CITY PROPERTY.
   All existing encroachments on City sidewalks and City property are hereby
authorized and continuance of such encroachments are hereby authorized, subject
to the following terms and conditions:
   (a)   That all City regulations be complied with;
   (b)    That such existing encroachments be improved, repaired or altered and
made safe as directed by the Director of Public Works;
   (c)    The owner of property encroaching on City property save the City
harmless from any and all liability by reason of such encroachment by either
posting a properly executed bond or a certificate of insurance, to which the
City is a party, in such an amount and in such form and under such conditions
as approved by the Director of Finance, the Director of Public Works and the
Director of Law;
   (d)    That the owner of such property make application within thirty days
after the effective date of this section or after notification by the Director
of Public Works of such encroachment, to the Director of Public Works for a
permit under this section to continue such existing encroachment, and
compliance with the terms herein set forth. (Ord. 6202. Passed 8-17-60.)
   901.02 LAYING UNDERGROUND PIPES PRIOR TO PAVING STREET.
   Whenever any street or other thoroughfare is about to be paved or otherwise
permanently improved or macadamized, all persons owning any property abutting
thereon shall be required to lay all necessary pipes or other underground
connections from sewer, water or other mains to the property line, and if any
person fails to do so within thirty days after service of notice to do so, the
work will be done by the City and the cost thereof assessed upon the lot or
parcel of land.
(1931 Code §27.2221)
   901.03 OBSTRUCTIONS.
   (a)    Definitions.
      (1)    "Street furnishings" shall include street furniture including but
not limited to benches, tables, chairs, table umbrellas, planters, waste
containers, news racks, mailboxes, and similar personal property used to vend a
product or for aesthetic display.
      (2)    "Bench" A seat or seats located on public sidewalks, along any
public way or right-of-way, for accommodation of persons awaiting
transportation or other purposes. This definition includes benches that may or
may not have advertising located anywhere on their exterior.
      (3)    "Modular news rack" A news rack which is designated with multiple
separate enclosed compartments able to accommodate the display, sale or
distribution of multiple distinct and separate newspapers, which exceeds the
dimensions of an individual news rack.
      (4)    "News rack" Any type of self-service device for the vending or
free distribution of newspapers, advertisements, or periodicals of any nature.
      (5)    "Newspaper” A publication of general circulation that is printed
and distributed, either daily or weekly, which contains news, current events,
features, advertising and/or information of interest to the general public,
often distributed through the use of news racks.
      (6)    "Planter" A container for plants, trees, bushes or other
vegetation.
      (7)    "Public right-of-way" All areas deeded to the public, or dedicated
to the public by formal dedication or by operation of law, that are legally
open to public use such as public streets, sidewalks, roadways, highways,
alleys, parkways, parks as well as areas surrounding and immediately adjacent
to public buildings.
      (8)    "Shelter" An enclosed or semi-enclosed structure, with or without
seats, located on any public right-of-way for the accommodation of persons
awaiting transportation or for other purposes.
      (9)    "Vending machine" Any machine that dispenses a product to the
general public including, but not limited to soft drink machines, cigar or
cigarette vending machines, food vending machines, coffee vending machines, and
live bait vending machines, but excluding news rack vending machines.
   (b)    Obstruction on or in the Public Right-of-Way Prohibited.
      (1)    No obstruction shall be allowed on or in a public right-of-way
including public sidewalks or streets, unless otherwise provided herein or
elsewhere in the Codified Ordinances of the City of Hamilton. Prohibited items
include, but are not limited to, items such as: shelters, benches and vending
machines.
      (2)    Non-compliance. The Director of Public Works or his/her designee
shall inform the offending entity in writing, at its last known business and/or
home address, that it has ten (10) days from the date of the notice to remove
the obstruction from the right-of-way or public property. If the obstruction is
not removed within ten (10) days, the City shall have the right to remove the
obstruction at the violator's cost. The reasonable cost associated with
removing the obstruction, including any costs paid to a contractor, shall be
passed along to the violator in addition to a two hundred dollars ($200.00)
administrative fee. Reasonable costs shall include, but not be limited to the
time of personnel involved, cost of fuel, cost of machinery, and the size,
nature or character of the lot or parcel of land, as well as any and all other
expenses for the performance of such labor and services provided, including an
administrative fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00).
         A.    Repeat Violators. For the second or continued violations of the
same general character, on property whereby the owner(s) or occupant(s)
received notice under subsection (d) hereof, occurring not sooner than fourteen
(14) days and not later than two (2) years after the previous violation, the
written notice contained in subsection (b)(2) hereof may be omitted and a
violation notice, specifying that the violation shall be corrected within
seventy-two (72) hours of receipt of said violation notice, shall be personally
served upon the offending entity or posted on the premises if the owner(s) or
occupant(s) cannot with reasonable diligence be located. If the violation is
not corrected by the specified compliance date by the owner, occupant or other
person or entity under subsection b hereof, the City shall cause such removal
to be undertaken at the expense of the offending party, and may employ the
necessary reasonable costs as outlined in subsection (b)(2).
      (3)    Exceptions. The following exceptions shall be allowed, subject to
the condition that the item(s) placed on or in a right-of-way or public
property do not create safety hazards by blocking reasonable access to or
passage through a right-of-way, or egress and ingress to an adjoining
entranceway, or by obstructing vehicular traffic sight lines or distances:
         A.    Sandwich board advertising abutting a licensed business, if
permitted by the City of Hamilton Zoning Code.
         B.   Planters or landscaping features/items.
         C.    Set out of trash, rubbish, garbage and recyclables as permitted
elsewhere in these Codified Ordinances.
         D.    Any property placed in the right-of-way by a governmental or
quasi- governmental agency or body, including but not limited to traffic
control and directional signs and devices, fire hydrants, emergency call boxes,
United States Postal Service mail receptacles or boxes, telephones, electrical
and light poles, benches and identifying signs as required or permitted by law.
         E.    Temporary scaffolding or other materials related to exterior
building renovation and/or construction, subject to the conditions set forth in
these Codified Ordinances.
         F.    Any obstruction otherwise allowed by the Codified Ordinances of
the City of Hamilton, Ohio.
   (c)    News Racks. News racks may be placed in the public rights-of-way,
subject to the following conditions and/or restrictions.
      (1)    It shall be unlawful for any owner to place, affix, erect,
construct or maintain a news rack upon any public sidewalk or public right-of-
way without first having obtained written permission for the placement and
location from the City's Director of Public Works or his/her designee, in
accordance with the provisions of this Section.
         A.    An applicant shall submit a written request for placement of a
news rack to the City's Director of Public Works with the following
information:
            1.    The name, address, telephone number, and email address of the
person/entity responsible for the news rack;
            2.    The name, address, telephone number, and email address of the
person who the City's Director of Public Works should notify or contact at any
time concerning the permittee's news rack;
            3.    The number, location, position, and installation method of a
news rack shown on a reasonably scaled map/drawing or aerial photograph;
            4.    Names of publications to be contained in each news rack,
frequency of distribution, and restocking schedule; and
            5.    A description and dimension of the news rack.
         B.    The City Director of Public Works or his designee shall issue a
written decision to an applicant within thirty (30) days of the submission of a
written request containing the required information indicated in subsection (c)
(1)A.
         C.    Any denial or decision regarding an applicant's proposed
placement of a newsrack in the right-of-way may be appealed to the Office of
the City Manager within thirty (30) days of the denial or decision. The
decision of the City Manager shall be final.
      (2)    News racks shall have the following dimensions:
         A.    The height shall not exceed sixty-two (62) inches;
         B.    The width, measured at the widest point shall not exceed thirty
(30) inches;
         C.    The depth, measured at the widest point, shall not exceed
twenty- four (24) inches.
      (3)   News racks may not be bolted or permanently affixed to any public
sidewalk or improved right-of-way unless such installation is approved by the
City Director of Public Works or his/her designee. If approved, installation
will be in a manner that conforms with the requirements herein, and to ensure
minimum damage to the right-of-way infrastructure.
      (4)    News racks which are not bolted or permanently attached to any
public sidewalk or public right-of-way shall be secured by a weighted base or
pedestal to prevent the newsracks from being tipped over, upset by the elements
or by contact from pedestrians.
      (5)    News racks shall not be chained or otherwise attached to any tree,
bench, signpost, electric or other utility pole or any other fixture.
      (6)    Each news rack shall be regularly maintained by its owner in a
reasonably clean, neat and attractive condition, and be in good repair at all
times to that:
         A.    It is kept free from graffiti; and
         B.    It is kept free of chipped, faded, peeling, or cracked paint in
the visibly painted areas thereof; and
         C.    It is kept free of rust and corrosion in the visible unpainted
metal areas thereof; and
         D.   The clear glass or plastic parts thereof, if any, through which
the printed material being dispensed are not broken and are kept free of tears,
peeling, fading and clouding, cracks, dents and discoloration;
         E.    The structural parts are not broken or unduly misshapen.
         F.    If a news rack is equipped with a coin return mechanism to
permit a person using the machine to secure an immediate refund in the event
he/she is unable to receive the publication paid for, the coin return mechanism
shall be maintained in good working order.
      (7)    In the event that an owner shall completely remove the news rack
and any mounting attachment, the owner shall be required to restore the
location to a safe condition, leaving no defect or projection in the pavement.
      (8)    Any news rack that is abandoned or that fails to comply with any
of the requirements set forth herein, may be removed by the City after
providing a ten-day (10) notice to the owner that the news rack has been deemed
abandoned or is not in compliance. A news rack will be considered abandoned
when any news rack does not contain the newspaper specified therein for more
than seven consecutive days for a daily publication, or fourteen (14)
consecutive days for a weekly publication or any other magazine or
informational material.
      (9)    News racks shall be placed in locations that do not obstruct or
interfere with ingress to or egress from abutting properties and which do not
impede or endanger pedestrians or vehicular traffic.
      (10)    News racks shall not be placed:
         A.    Upon a public sidewalk or public right-of-way in a manner that
blocks ingress or egress to a building, or a readily identifiable or marked
loading zone, or a handicapped parking space, or within 150 feet of another
news rack; or
         B.    Within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant; or
         C.    Within two (2) feet of a parking meter, mailbox, bench, light
post, planter or tree grate; or
         D.    On any portion of a tree grate, manhole cover, meter and/or
valve box cover, or cover for underground utilities; or
         E.    At any location whereby the clear space on the public sidewalks
for passageway of pedestrians is reduced to less than four (4) feet; or
         F.    In such a manner as to obstruct the sight lines at street
intersections that creates safety hazards for pedestrians and vehicle
occupants; or
         G.    In such a manner where the door of the news rack opens beyond
the edge of a street curb.
      (11)    As a condition to receiving the written permission, the news rack
permittee shall provide a Certificate of Insurance naming the City of Hamilton,
Ohio as an additional insured in an amount not less than one million dollars
($1,000,000) sufficient to indemnify the City of Hamilton, and further shall
release and indemnify, defend and save harmless the City of Hamilton, Ohio, its
officers, elected officials, agents, and employees from and against any and all
claims, actions, demands, judgment costs, expenses, and damages of every kind
and nature incurred by or incurring to any person whatsoever predicated upon
injury or death of any person, or loss of or damage to property, public or
private, or whatever ownership, or damages to business, provided such injury,
death, or loss or damage shall arise out of or be connected directly or
indirectly to the exercise of any right or privilege granted by any written
permission issued under this Section.
         (Ord. 2022-4-30. Passed 4-27-22.)
   901.04 MERCHANDISE ON THOROUGHFARES.
   Except in the market and during market hours as established and provided
under the provisions of Chapter
717 of the Business Regulation Code, and except as street vendors may carry on
the business for which they are licensed under the provisions of Chapter
754 of said Code, no person shall place, store or keep merchandise in piles or
containers, on counters, benches, parked vehicles or otherwise upon any part of
sidewalk, street or other thoroughfare or public place, for the purpose of
selling such merchandise there, or for any other purpose other than such
temporary deposit as may be necessary in the transfer of such merchandise or
commodities between the premises and conveyances in the thoroughfare in the
regular course of business. However, the provisions of this section shall not
be construed to apply to building or construction materials for use on any work
or construction authorized by or under the authority of any other ordinance
provision to be stored or kept in or upon any sidewalk, street or other
thoroughfare.
(Ord. 2016-4-25. Passed 4-13-16.)
   901.05 BARRIERS BETWEEN LOT LINE AND CURB LINE.
   No person shall erect or maintain any fence, wire or other barrier between
the lot line and the curb line of any street. (1931 Code §22.6272)
   901.06 DIRECTIONAL INDICATIONS.
   The City is hereby divided by:
   (a)    A north-south line to be known as the City meridian, which shall
follow the center line of the Great Miami River, and by
   (b)    An east-west base line, which shall follow the center line of High
and Main Streets from the Great Miami River to Millville Ave., and Millville
Ave., from Main Street to the western corporation line.
   Names of thoroughfares in that section of the City east of the City meridian
and north of the base line shall bear the suffix N.E., meaning North East;
similarly, names of thoroughfares in each other section of the City. marked off
by the City meridian and the base line shall, respectively, bear the proper
suffix, S.E., N.W., or S.W. (1931 Code §20.4100)
   901.07 NAMING OF ALLEYS.
   Each alley shall be known and designated by the same name as the parallel
street immediately north, or immediately east of such alley, as the case may
be. In case two or more alleys occur between any two streets, the alley nearest
the street from which they are to be named shall bear the letter "A" as suffix
to its name, the next "B" and so on.
(1931 Code §20.4171)
   901.08 GUY WIRES.
   No person by his agents, employees or otherwise, shall attach to any tree or
trees, or to the boxing or other protection surrounding the same, or to any
building either public or private, any guy wire, brace wire or other
contrivance intended to keep straight any pole or post, or for any other
purpose, without having first obtained permission from the owner or agent of
such property, which permission such owner or agent may at any time revoke
after five days' notice to such permittee or his agent; and if such properly
belongs to the City, then by obtaining permission from the Director of Public
Works, which permission may at his discretion be revoked after five days'
notice as above specified. If any such guy wire, brace wire or other such
contrivance be so attached to any tree, tree box or building belonging to the
City, without a City permit, or if upon revocation of any such permit it is not
detached or removed within five days, the Director of Public Works shall remove
the same, unless it is entirely upon private property. (1931 Code §93.3421)
   901.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates the provisions of Section
901.03 of obstructing the right of way is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third
degree. Each subsequent violation is a misdemeanor of the second degree. In
addition, offenders will forfeit their goods upon each conviction.
   (b)   Whoever violates any other provision of this chapter shall be fined
not more than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).
(Ord. 2010-5-38. Passed 5-25-10.)
CHAPTER 903
Streets
903.01    Minimum pavement standards.
903.02   Snow and ice emergency; prohibition of parking on City streets.
903.99    Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Assessments - see CHTR. Art. XIII
      Power to establish and care for streets - see Ohio R. C. 715.19, 717.01,
723.01
      Openings by the Municipality - see Ohio R. C. 723.02
      Dedication and acceptance - see Ohio R. C. 723.03
      Change of name, vacating and narrowing streets - see Ohio R. C. 723.04 et
seq.
      Sprinkling - see Ohio R. C. 723.16 et seq.
      Surface treatment - see Ohio R. C. 723.23, 723.31
      Excavation liability - see Ohio R. C. 723.49 et seq.
      Changing established grade - see Ohio R. C. 727.07
      Compulsory service connections - see Ohio R. C. 729.06, 743.37
      Digging, excavating and piling earth on streets - see Ohio R. C. 5589.10
   903.01 MINIMUM PAVEMENT STANDARDS.
   All improvements constructed within public rights of way shall be in
accordance with the established procedures and specifications of the Department
of Public Works. No street shall be accepted unless the work has been inspected
and approved by the Director of Public Works.
   All pavement construction shall be in accordance with the latest edition of
the "Ohio Department of Transportation Construction and Material
Specifications", including all supplemental specifications, revisions and
amendments thereto. All of the following item designations are as specified and
defined in these specifications:
(Ord. 6648. Passed 6-3-64.)
   (a)    Flexible Pavement Design.
       Base Structure:
      (l)   Minimum five inches of item 301 Bituminous Aggregate Base; or
      (2)    Aggregate base material may be used where adequate subsurface
drainage is provided. Thickness shall be based on soil tests and design
calculations approved by the City Engineer.
      Surface Structure:
          Three inches of compacted asphaltic concrete pavement, placed in two
courses of l-l/2" of Item 403 and l-l/2" of Item 404.
         (Ord. 87-4-37. Passed 4-22-87.)
   (b)    Rigid Pavement Design.
      Rigid pavement shall be constructed of 7" of Portland cement concrete,
Item 452.
      Concrete curbs and gutters may be constructed integral with the pavement.
   (c)    Subsurface Drainage.
      Subsurface drainage shall be required on all streets constructed with
granular base material and may be required for all types of pavement structure
where soil and underground water conditions warrant. This requirement may be
waived for uniform and pervious soils provided the engineer submits sufficient
and supporting soil tests and engineering data that natural drainage will be
adequate and satisfactory. (Ord. 6648. Passed 6-3-64.)
   903.02 SNOW AND ICE EMERGENCY; PROHIBITION OF PARKING ON CITY STREETS.
   (a)   The City Manager or his designee, at his/her discretion, may declare a
snow and ice emergency during periods of inclement weather. During any declared
snow and ice emergency, the parking of motor vehicles upon the streets of the
City shall be restricted as follows:
      (1)   If a snow and ice emergency is declared on an even calendar date,
the parking of all motor vehicles shall be prohibited on the side of all City
streets having an even address number. Upon the plowing, salting and clearing
of such even side of any street, the parking of motor vehicles shall be
permitted on such even side of the street; and immediately following the
clearing of the even side of such street, the parking of all motor vehicles
shall be prohibited on the odd side of such street to facilitate the plowing,
salting and clearing of the odd side of such street.
      (2)   If a snow and ice emergency is declared on an odd calendar date,
the parking of all motor vehicles shall be prohibited on the side of all City
streets having an odd address number. Upon the plowing, salting and clearing of
the odd side of any street, the parking of motor vehicles shall be permitted on
such odd side of the street; and immediately following the clearing of the odd
side of such street, the parking of all motor vehicles shall be prohibited on
the even side of such street to facilitate the plowing, salting and clearing of
the even side of such street.
   (b)   All motor vehicles parked upon any street whereupon the parking of
motor vehicles is prohibited during a snow and ice emergency shall be towed and
impounded.
   (c)   All other parking prohibitions shall be suspended during the period in
which a snow and ice emergency is in effect.
   (d)   The City Manager may establish policies and procedures to effectuate
snow and ice emergencies as provided for herein.
(Ord. 99-10-108. Passed 10-13-99.)
 
   903.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00).
CHAPTER 905
Building Numbering
905.01   General provisions.
905.02   Numbers per footage.
905.03   Existing and new numbers.
905.04   Number to be displayed.
905.05   Failure to display numbers.
905.06   Maps of premises.
905.07   Offenses.
905.99    Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate building numbering - see Ohio R. C. 715.26
   905.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   Premises shall be numbered in either direction from the City meridian or the
base line. For the purposes of this section a block shall include all the
premises facing any thoroughfare between two intersecting streets or avenues,
as the case may be. However, if two streets or two avenues are nearer together
throughout the principal part of their length than 600 feet, or further apart
than 600 feet, premises within the area affected by such irregularity shall be
numbered in arbitrary blocks so as to conform substantially to the numbers
given premises similarly situated in other parts of the City. Numbers up to 99
shall be used for premises within the first block in either direction from the
City meridian or from the base line, and not parallel thereto; numbers
beginning with 100 and thence up to 199 shall be used in the next succeeding
block, and so on. Even numbers shall be used upon the northerly and easterly
sides, and odd numbers on the southerly and westerly sides of the
thoroughfares. (1931 Code §20.4610.)
   905.02 NUMBERS PER FOOTAGE.
   In general, one number will be allowed on each side of a thoroughfare each
twenty five feet in residence blocks, and for each twenty feet in business
blocks. (1931 Code §20.4621)
   905.03 EXISTING AND NEW NUMBERS.
   Numbers officially assigned to, or in use upon premises at the time this
section becomes effective are hereby confirmed, subject to change or correction
in the manner provided by this chapter. It shall be the duty of the Director of
Public Works to assign the proper numbers to premises not numbered at such
time, and to premises laid out upon plats thereafter. When areas are annexed to
the City, and County numbers have been assigned thereto, such numbers shall
continue to be used. No building permit shall be issued in respect of any
premises not numbered as herein required. In case of disputes as to the use of
any particular number or numbers, the Director of Public Works shall assign
proper numbers to the premises affected, according to the principles prescribed
in this chapter. The Director of Public Works shall have power, in case numbers
in use on any premises do not conform to the principles prescribed in this
chapter, to renumber such premises in accordance therewith. (Ord. 5934. Passed
3-5-58.)
   905.04 NUMBER TO BE DISPLAYED.
   The owner, occupant or person in charge of any premises upon which a
building is located shall place at each street entrance to such premises the
proper building number for such entrance, as confirmed by this chapter or as
assigned by the Director of Public Works.
   In the event a building is located upon the premises so that it faces an
alley at the rear or side of such premises, then the building number for the
premises shall be placed upon the building located in closest proximity to the
alley.
   The foregoing building numbers shall be placed so that they can be clearly
seen from the street or alley which they face. Such numbers shall not be less
than four inches in height. All new construction following the effective date
of this section shall have illuminated or reflectorized building numbers not
less than four inches in height.
(Ord. 88-10-87. Passed 10-26-88.)
   905.05 FAILURE TO DISPLAY NUMBERS.
   If the Director of Public Works finds any premises the entrances to which
are not numbered as required in this chapter, or that numbers are not properly
placed, or are illegible or obscure, he shall notify the owner, occupant or
person in charge, requiring him within ten days to install, relocate, replace
or make legible the proper numbers, in compliance with the provisions of this
chapter and to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Works.
(1931 Code §20.4648)
   905.06 MAPS OF PREMISES.
   It shall be the duty of the Director of Public Works to cause a map or maps
to be prepared, showing all premises, and showing the fronts of all structures
thereon and the entrances thereto required to be numbered, and the number
assigned to each entrance and at least one number assigned to or reserved for
each lot or parcel not built upon.
(1931 Code §20.4681)
   905.07 OFFENSES.
   (a)   No person shall exhibit upon any premises a number having the general
appearance of a street number, the use of which has not been confirmed or
assigned to such premises, or the use of which has been confirmed or assigned
to other premises on the same thoroughfare.
   (b)   No person, having been notified so to do by the Director of Public
Works, shall fail within ten days after receipt of such notice to place,
relocate, replace or make legible the proper number at the entrance of the
premises owned or occupied or in charge of such person.
   (c)   No person shall destroy or deface any number put up in conformity with
the provisions of this chapter. (1931 Code §20.4693)
   905.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00).
CHAPTER 907

CROSS REFERENCES
      Liability for damage - see Ohio R. C. 723.49 et seq.
      Barricades and warning lights; abandoned excavations - see GEN. OFF.
521.03 
      Tampering with safety device - see GEN. OFF.
541.04 
   907.01 PERMIT REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS.
   No person, other than a contractor in the performance of public work
pursuant to a contract with the City, and other than the Director of Public
Works or his subordinates authorized by him to do so shall make any opening,
excavation, or cut in or remove any pavement, sod or other surface material
from any street or other thoroughfare, or from any park or other public
grounds, unless such person has applied for and received from the Director of
Public Works a permit to do so. But the provisions of this and the next
succeeding sections shall not apply to openings or excavations made for the
setting of poles or posts. (1931 Code §27.3012)
   907.02 PERMIT APPLICATION; FEE.
   The application for an excavation permit shall set forth the number, size
and location of excavations desired to be made, or the location and extent of
pavement or other surface desired to be removed, shall state the purpose
thereof, and shall state the method of excavation and of making connections
intended to be used. At the time of filing such application the applicant shall
pay to the City five dollars ($5.00) as reimbursement for any cost of necessary
preliminary investigations or inspections.
   907.03 DEPOSIT FOR RESTORATION; NONLIABILITY OF CITY.
   The Director of Public Works shall not issue any permit to cut or excavate
any street, thoroughfare, park or other public ground unless for some lawful
purpose, and unless such cut or excavation is reasonably necessary. He may, in
granting any permit, modify any particulars of the application therefor, and
impose conditions therein, for the purpose of minimizing any inconvenience or
injury to the public and the public property thereby. He shall not issue such
permit until the applicant has deposited with the Director of Finance a sum of
money sufficient to defray the cost of refilling such excavation, removing any
excess materials, and restoring the pavement or other surface as may be
required by ordinance and to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Works,
nor until the applicant shall have given security satisfactory to the Director
of Law that he will save the City harmless from all claims for damage by reason
of any excavation or other work done under such permit.
   The deposit to be made under this section shall be at the rate of fifteen
dollars ($15.00) per square yard or remaining fraction thereof in the case of
improved streets, and at the rate of five dollars ($5.00) per square yard in
the case of unimproved streets or in other places.
   907.04 DRIVING OF PIPES IN LIEU OF EXCAVATION; TUNNELING.
   The Director of Public Works may require the driving of pipes in cases where
and to the extent that soil conditions and other circumstances render such
driving practicable, in lieu of excavation. Tunneling shall not be permitted in
any case unless the Director of Public Works deems it more suitable than driven
pipe or open cut, and unless the applicant gives security satisfactory to the
Director of Law to save the City harmless from any future settling or injury of
the surface or of the pavement. (1931 Code §27.3122)
   907.05 TIME LIMIT.
   All excavation in the streets, thoroughfares, parks and public places, and
all work therein, and the restoration thereof shall be carried on and completed
without delay, as soon as possible after it has been begun. The person in
charge of the excavation shall notify the Director of Public Works when work is
begun. In the excavation permit the Director of Public Works may specify or
restrict the hours when work is to be carried on, and may require that during
hours when work is not in progress, or in hours when traffic requirements
justify it, every such excavation or any part thereof designated by him, in any
street or thoroughfare, shall be securely covered over with such materials and
in such manner as to permit the passage of vehicular and pedestrian traffic
with the least interference or delay.
   907.06 DEBRIS.
   Material from any excavation in any street, thoroughfare, park or public
ground not to be used for refilling or backfilling such excavation, shall be
promptly removed and disposed of by the grantee of the permit without expense
to the City. If the grantee fails to remove such material, no future permit
will be granted by the Director of Public Works until the City has been
reimbursed the cost of removing such material. Excavated materials which will
be used in refilling or backfilling shall be piled in such place and in such
manner as will least interfere with the public, and as the Director of Public
Works shall direct.
(1931 Code, §27.3220)
   907.07 SIDES AND FACES OF EXCAVATION; BRACING.
   The sides or exposed faces of all excavations except those made in rock or
hard slag which, in all the case of tunnels, are of any depth whatsoever, which
in the case of trenches extend more than five feet in depth and which in the
case of all other excavations except shafts on tunnel work extend more than ten
feet in depth below the surface from which the excavation as a whole was or is
started, shall be supported and held in place by sheeting or sheet piling and
bracing and/or shoring and/or other devices, means or methods, all of which is
hereinafter referred to as the bracing system, in such manner as to prevent
such sliding, slipping, caving, squeezing or other movement as would endanger,
either directly or indirectly, the lives of, or subject to injury, the
employees and/or workmen working in the excavation.
   Conformity with these requirements is not necessary, however, if and when
the sides or exposed faces of such excavations are sloped to the angle of
repose of the material being excavated.
   Such bracing system shall be designed to resist all loads which it might
reasonably and in accordance with good engineering practice be expected to
support, including not only those resulting from the weight of the soil or
other material itself, but also those resulting from vehicular traffic,
streetcars, railroads, railways or other transportation facilities, surface
and/or subsurface structures, stored materials, including materials removed
from the excavation, stored or operating construction machinery or equipment
and/or previous excavations.
(Ord. 5138. Passed 9-20-50.)
   907.08 UNSUPPORTED SIDES AND FACES.
   The sides or exposed faces of excavations made in rock may be unsupported
except when the following conditions obtain:
   (a)    The sides or exposed faces are composed of loose, shattered, faulted
or disintegrated rock and/or pockets of clay or other soil, any or all of which
are so extensive and/or of such character as to endanger the lives of, or
subject to possible injury, the employees or workmen in or near or required to
be in or near the excavation.
   (b)    The rock is seamed and such seams lie at an angle of 30° or more with
the horizontal and are filled with clay or other material upon which the rock
might slide.
   (c)    In shale excavations, if, within the duration of the work, the shale
tends to disintegrate. (Ord. 5138. Passed 9-20-50.)
   907.09 BRACING SYSTEM.
   (a)    The erection of the bracing system shall be carried along
simultaneously with the excavation. At no time shall the sides or exposed faces
of any excavation be unsupported.
   A temporary bracing system may be provided for a vertical distance of not
more than five feet but only for such time as it is necessary to permit
erection of the required bracing system.
   In hard compact materials in the cases of trenches where mechanical
excavating equipment of the pull-shovel, dragline trenching machine or similar
type of equipment, is used or in the case of other excavations, excluding
tunnels, less than twenty feet in depth, the erection of the bracing system may
be withheld, but not to exceed twenty-four hours until the excavation is
completed. Such unsupported trench shall not extend more than sixteen feet
beyond the bucket in its most extended position at the ground surface. The
sides of such other excavations may remain unsupported only to such extent and
for such time as is necessary to permit operation of the mechanical excavating
equipment being used.
   Excavated or other material shall not be stored within eighteen inches of
the side of the excavation. (Ord. 5138. Passed 9-20-50.)
   (b)   Notwithstanding the requirements of Sections 907.07 to 907.09, the
provisions of the Occupational Safety and Health Act shall apply where
applicable.
   907.10 EXCAVATION WARNINGS.
   If any excavation is left open, or if any excavated material is left near
the excavation, during the nighttime sufficient red lights or lanterns, and
during the daytime sufficient red flags and barriers, shall be placed thereon
and thereby to warn of their presence.
   If the City is required to place such excavational warnings because the
permit grantee has failed to do so, no further excavation permit will be
granted to such person until the City has been reimbursed the cost of such
placement.
   907.11 TAMPERING WITH WARNING DEVICE.
   No person shall destroy, remove, displace, extinguish or in any way
interfere with any light, signal, barricade or other warning of any nature
whatsoever which is placed at or near any excavation, obstruction or other
dangerous place in the streets or other thoroughfares, or in any other public
ground or public place for the purpose of warning and protecting persons except
as authorized and directed to do so by the proper authority or by the persons
responsible for placing and maintaining such lights, signals, barricades or
warnings. (1931 Code §27.3225)
   907.12 BACKFILLING.
   It shall be the duty of every person who makes any excavation in any street,
thoroughfare, park or public ground, as soon as the installation or connection
therein is made, to backfill such excavation up to the surface, with earth or
backfilling material in layers not deeper than nine inches each, thoroughly
compacted by ramming or flushing. The grantee shall maintain such backfilling
until the surface is restored as provided in Section
907.13. If the grantee of any permit fails to do any such backfilling to the
satisfaction of the Director of Public Works, he shall upon being required to
do so, remove all unsatisfactory backfilling and replace it as required, or the
Director of Public Works shall do so at the cost and expense of such grantee.
(1931 Code §27. 3312)
   907.13 RESTORATION BY DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS.
   The Director of Public Works shall, as soon as practicable after any
excavation has been made in any street, thoroughfare, park or public ground,
restore the pavement or other surfacing thereon, unless in the case of another
City department or other person properly equipped and competent to do so, he
shall authorize such restoration to be made by the person making the
excavation. When the pavement or other surfacing is restored to the Director's
satisfaction, he shall determine the cost to the City of such restoration,
including the cost of all inspections, of all backfilling done by the City, of
all labor and material expended in repairing or resurfacing, and a reasonable
charge for overhead services, and shall certify such cost to the Director of
Finance, who shall thereupon issue a receiving warrant or voucher, to transfer
to the General Fund so much of the deposit made in respect of such improvement
as may be necessary to defray the cost so certified, and shall return any
balance in such deposit to the depositor. If the cost so certified exceeds the
amount deposited, the Director of Finance shall proceed forthwith to collect
the remainder due the City. (1931 Code §27.3382)
   907.14 EFFECT OF NONCOMPLIANCE.
   The Director of Public Works may refuse to issue any permit for excavation
in any street, thoroughfare, park or public place to any person who has failed
or refused or neglected to comply with all the requirements of this chapter, or
with the reasonable orders or requirements of the Director, or to pay any
balance due the City, by reason of work done in connection with permits
previously issued to him. (1931 Code §27.3812)
   907.15 WORK STARTED WITHOUT A PERMIT.
   When work for which a permit is required by this chapter, is started prior
to obtaining such permit, the fees required by the permit shall be doubled, but
the payment of such double fee shall not relieve any person from fully
complying with the requirements of this chapter, or any other law of the State
or ordinance of this City. The double fee shall be in addition to any penalty
provided by law.
   907.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed
each day during or on which an offense occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 909
Sidewalks
909.01    Supervision of construction.
909.02    Construction specifications.
909.03    Removal of snow and ice.
909.04    Defacement.
909.05    Nuisance removal from sidewalks, street lawns, curbs and gutters.
909.99    Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES

521.03
      Obstructions; damage - see GEN. OFF.
521.04
      Duty to keep sidewalks clean and in repair - see GEN. OFF.
521.06
      Tampering with safety device - see GEN. OFF.
541.04
   909.01 SUPERVISION OF CONSTRUCTION.
   All sidewalks shall be constructed under the supervision and inspection of
the Director of Public Works, whether the work is contracted and paid for
directly by the owners or otherwise. (1931 Code §22.3141)
   909.02 CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS.
   (a)    Forms. Forms for concrete sidewalk shall be of wood not less than two
inches in nominal thickness or steel of equal rigidity. Curved forms must be
approved by the Director of Public Works. The forms shall be securely held to
line and grade and shall at no time deviate more than 1/4 inch from an accurate
template ten feet in length. Forms shall be cleaned and oiled after each use.
   (b)    Traverse Slope. Unless otherwise specified, the surface of sidewalks
shall have a traverse slope of 1/4 inch per foot with the low side adjacent to
the roadway.
   (c)   Expansion Joints. Expansion joints shall be 1/2 inch and shall be
placed in such a manner that the joint will be flush with the surface of the
sidewalk and shall be constructed at intervals of not more than thirty feet.
Whenever concrete sidewalks abut other walks, steps, curbs, manholes, inlets or
adjacent building foundations, 1/4 inch expansion joint material shall be
installed.
   (d)    Placing and Finishing. The concrete shall be deposited and compacted
in a single course on a compacted surface. It shall be struck off with a
template and smoothed with a wood float to produce a sandy texture. The edges
shall be rounded to a 1/4 inch radius. The surface of sidewalk shall be divided
into blocks by use of a grooving tool. The grooves shall be spaced equally at
approximately four or five feet intervals to match the existing construction on
the street.
   (e)   Clean-Up. After construction is completed, forms shall be removed and
the void created therein shall be backfilled with soil to match existing
conditions.
   909.03 REMOVAL OF SNOW AND ICE.
   It shall be the duty of the owner of any premises abutting upon any public
sidewalk to remove from such sidewalk any snowfall thereon, and to remove any
accumulation or cover of ice from any such sidewalk, or to cover such ice with
sand or other substance so as to render it safe and convenient for passage
within a reasonable time. Failure to comply with the requirement of this
section shall be deemed to be a violation of this section.
   909.04 DEFACEMENT.
   No person shall deface or disfigure any sidewalk or part thereof by painting
or marking thereon any names, words, advertisements or any sign or device
whatever, or by pasting or placing any printed bills or posters thereon, or by
chiselling or cutting into such sidewalk, or by impressing or marking any name,
word, letter or device into such sidewalk before the same has hardened. (1931
Code §22.3933)
   909.05 NUISANCE REMOVAL FROM SIDEWALKS, STREET LAWNS, CURBS AND GUTTERS.
   No owner or occupant of abutting lands shall fail to keep the sidewalks,
street lawn, curbs or gutters free from any garbage, refuse, rubbish or any
other waste material the presence of which would tend to create a danger to
public health, safety or welfare.
   909.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00).
CHAPTER 910
Constructing or Repairing Sidewalks, Curbs, Gutters and Driveways: Private
Contractors
910.01   Work permit required.
910.02   Permit application.
910.03   Permit fees.
910.04   Denial of permit.
910.05   Work by owner.
910.06   Permit revocation.
910.07   Concrete contractor’s license required.
910.08   License fee.
910.09   Bond.
910.10   Inspection of work.
910.11   Adoption of rules and regulations.
910.99   Penalty.
   910.01 WORK PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person, as principal, agent or employee, whether an abutting owner or
otherwise, shall construct or repair, or attempt to construct or repair, any
public sidewalk, curb, gutter or driveway as hereinafter defined without first
having obtained a permit therefor from the Director of Public Works, or his
duly authorized representative. This chapter shall not apply to the
construction or repair of sidewalks, curbs, gutters and driveways under or by
virtue of a contract with the City. For purposes of this chapter, "driveway"
shall mean any area constructed within the public right-of-way connecting the
paved public roadway with private property for the purpose of providing access
for motor vehicles to private property.
(Ord. 98-11-117. Passed 11-11-98.)
   910.02 PERMIT APPLICATION.
   Written application for the permit required in Section
910.01 shall be in the name of and signed by the person proposing to perform
repair or construction of sidewalks, curbs, gutters and driveways. It shall
contain the name of the owner of the abutting property and such other
information as is required to identify the site of the work. A separate permit
shall be required for each lot or parcel of land involved. Only a licensed
concrete contractor, or the abutting property owner who is personally
performing such repair or construction, shall be granted a permit. Any person
granted such permit shall be subject to the following obligations to the City
in the exercise of the privilege hereby granted:
   (a)    To guard, provide warning signals and barriers and otherwise do any
and all things necessary to prevent injury to persons and property by reason of
any excavation, construction or other activity undertaken pursuant to such
permit;
   (b)    To indemnify and hold harmless the City from and against any claim,
demand, lawsuit or judgment of any person whatsoever, arising out of the
exercise of the privilege granted by such permit, and based on either property
damage or personal injury, or both, and to reimburse the City for any expense
incurred by it by reason of any such claim, demand, lawsuit or judgment, and to
assume responsibility for and to defend any lawsuit which may arise therefrom;
and
   (c)    In the case of a person, other than the owner of the abutting
property, to procure and furnish satisfactory evidence that he or it has
procured and is keeping in full force and effect a policy of liability
insurance, providing himself and the City with indemnification against any
claims, demands, lawsuits or judgments arising out of the exercise of the
privilege granted; such policy of liability insurance is to guarantee at least
fifty thousand dollars/one hundred thousand dollars ($50,000/$100,000) for
personal injuries and fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000) for property damage.
The requirements of this subsection may be dispensed with when, in the opinion
of the Director of Public Works, or his duly authorized representative, the
nature of the undertaking does not require same.
      (Ord. 98-11-117. Passed 11-11-98.)
   910.03 PERMIT FEES. 
   Fees for permits issued to construct or repair public sidewalks, curbs,
gutters and driveways shall be as follows:
 
 
Driveway repair        .25 per square foot
Sidewalk repair        .25 per square foot
Curb and gutter repair .50 per linear foot
Sidewalk construction  .25 per square foot
Curb construction      .50 per linear foot
(Ord. 98-11-117. Passed 11-11-98.)
   910.04 DENIAL OF PERMIT.
   The permit required in Section
910.01 shall not be granted if such granting will constitute an unreasonable
interference with the public in the use of any street, sidewalk, alley, lane or
other public place, or will constitute a menace to public safety.
(Ord. 98-11-117. Passed 11-11-98.)
   910.05 WORK BY OWNER.
   Any property owner who is personally performing such construction or repair
on the public right-of-way abutting such property must fully abide by and
conform to all of the provisions of this chapter, except the requirement of
posting bond, furnishing evidence of liability insurance and procuring a
license.
(Ord. 98-11-117. Passed 11-11-98.)
   910.06 PERMIT REVOCATION.
   Any permit granted by the Director of Public Works pursuant to this chapter
may be revoked by him at any time when in his opinion the terms of this chapter
are being violated, or when the continued exercise of the privilege constitutes
a menace to the public safety or is an unreasonable use of the public streets
or ways.
(Ord. 98-11-117. Passed 11-11-98.)
   910.07 CONCRETE CONTRACTOR’S LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, other than the abutting owner, shall undertake to construct or
repair any public sidewalk, curb, gutter, or driveway as defined in Section
910.01 without first having obtained a license as a concrete contractor. Such
license shall be dated as of the day of issue and shall expire one year
thereafter. Application for a license shall be made in writing to the Director
of Public Works who, if he is satisfied that the applicant is qualified to
properly construct and repair sidewalks, curbs, gutters and driveways, shall
issue such license upon payment of the fee required in Section
910.08 and upon filing the bond required in Section
910.09.
(Ord. 98-11-117. Passed 11-11-98.)
   910.08 LICENSE FEE.
   A fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be charged for each original
license required in Section
910.07 and a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each consecutive yearly renewal
thereof.
(Ord. 98-11-117. Passed 11-11-98.)
   910.09 BOND.
   Before receiving the license required in Section
910.07, the applicant shall file a surety bond in the sum of ten thousand
dollars ($10,000) with the Director of Public Works, approved by the Director
of Law, conditioned upon the faithful observance of the provisions of this
chapter and other applicable provisions of City ordinances and the
specifications and rules and regulations of the Director of Public Works
pertaining to the construction and repair of public sidewalks, curbs, gutters
and driveways. Such bond shall further provide for payment to the City, or all
persons entitled thereto, of the cost and expense of reconstructing any
sidewalk, curb, gutter or driveway should any defect due to construction,
material or workmanship, or due to the contractor's failure to conform to the
specifications and rules and regulations relating to the construction or repair
of sidewalks, curbs, gutters and driveways, develop in such work at any time
within a period of one year from January 1 next following the completion of the
work. Such bond shall be further conditioned to indemnify and save harmless the
City on account of any and all claims or damages or injuries to persons or
property due to failure of the contractor to maintain the right of way where
such construction or repair is being done in a condition which is safe and fit
for public travel, and in compliance with the provisions of this Chapter, and
any amendment hereto, or any rules and regulations relating to public safety
now in effect or which may hereinafter be enacted.
(Ord. 98-11-117. Passed 11-11-98.)
   910.10 INSPECTION OF WORK.
   The Director of Public Works shall have on file in his office the
specifications and rules and regulations regulating the manner in which
sidewalks, curbs, gutters and driveways are to be constructed or repaired. When
any part of the construction or repair work is completed, the Director of
Public Works, or his duly authorized representative, shall make an inspection
of the work. If the work is unsatisfactory, he shall, by mail or otherwise,
serve written notice of such fact on the contractor and the property owner, and
order the contractor or property owner to reconstruct or repair the work
according to such specifications.
(Ord. 98-11-117. Passed 11-11-98.)
   910.11 ADOPTION OF RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Director of Public Works is hereby authorized to make and adopt such
rules and regulations governing the exercise of permits and licenses issued
under this chapter as he may deem necessary and proper for the administration
of this chapter. No person shall violate or fail to comply with any such rule
or regulation.
(Ord. 98-11-117. Passed 11-11-98.)
   910.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 98-11-117. Passed 11-11-98.)
CHAPTER 911
Poles
911.01    Permit required.

911.05    Use of poles by others.

911.08    Removal.
911.09    Statement and map.
911.10    Compliance required.
911.99    Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to regulate electricity equipment - see Ohio R. C. 715.27
   City consent for electrical fixtures and lines on public property - see Ohio
      R.C. 715.27, 4933.13, 4933.16
   Power to require permit for facility construction or location - see Ohio R.
C.
      4905.65
   City consent for telephone fixtures and lines on public property - see Ohio
      R.C. 4931.20, 4931.23

901.08 
   911.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall erect, set or maintain any pole or post in or upon any
street or other thoroughfare, or in or upon any park or other public ground of
the City, unless he shall have applied for and received a permit to do so. No
person shall use the posts or poles of another, or grant or permit the use of
his poles or posts by another, without the consent and approval of the Director
of Public Works. (1931 Code §22.6303)
   911.02 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   The application for a pole permit shall state the number of poles or posts
desired; the location, height above the surface, depth of setting,
reinforcement or guying, number of wires, cables or other fixtures or
appurtenances to be supported by each; and the relation to other poles or posts
used by the same applicant. The Director of Public Works, may, in granting the
permit, modify any of the particulars of the application. (1931 Code §22.6312)
   911.03 RELOCATION AND REPLACEMENT.
   It shall be a condition of every pole permit, and of the continued use of
the streets, thoroughfares, parks and other public grounds for poles or posts,
that upon the demand or order of the Director of Public Works to do so, the
owner or person responsible for such poles or posts shall at his own expense
relocate or replace any such pole or post so as not to interfere with any
public improvement, or so as to conform to any general relocation of such poles
or posts throughout the City or within any block or blocks, or so as to remove
any dangerous condition.
(1931 Code §22.6323)
   911.04 USE OF POLES FOR WIRING.
   It shall be a condition of every permit hereafter issued for any pole or
post that the City shall be entitled to use the same for carrying the necessary
wires or cables of the police or fire signal systems of the City. (1931 Code
§22.6324)
   911.05 USE OF POLES BY OTHERS.
   It shall be a condition of every permit hereafter issued for any pole or
post that to the extent of any capacity of such pole or post not in use or
presently to be required for the use of the grantee of such permit, and upon
being required to do so by the Director of Public Works, such grantee shall,
for a reasonable compensation, allow the use of such pole or post by others who
would otherwise require poles or posts at or about the same place. When there
exists sufficient capacity on existing poles or posts to care for the needs of
any applicant for a permit to erect other poles or posts, the Director of
Public Works may in lieu of granting such permit require such other applicant
to use poles or posts already erected. The purpose of this section is to
conserve the space of streets and other public places by minimizing the number
of poles or posts which shall be erected therein. (1931 Code §22.6325)
   911.06 ENDANGERING AND INTERFERING.
   The Director of Public Works shall not grant a permit for any pole or post
which by its location, size or things to be supported would in any way endanger
the life or property of persons lawfully in or upon or near the streets,
thoroughfares or other public grounds occupied by such pole or post, or which
would in any manner interfere with the free passage of traffic upon the
streets, sidewalks or other thoroughfares. (1931 Code §22.6321)
   911.07 REVOCATION OF PERMIT.
   The Director of Public Works shall have the power, and it shall be his duty,
to revoke any and all permits grant to any person, under the provisions of this
chapter whenever any such person or corporation refuses or neglects to maintain
any such pole or post in a safe condition, or to comply with any provision of
ordinance or with any reasonable order or requirement of the Director of Public
Works in respect thereto. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to
derogate from the power of Council to require at any time the removal,
relocation or replacement of any pole or post, whether a permit for it has been
issued or not. (1931 Code §22.6341)
   911.08 REMOVAL.
   It shall be the duty of the owner or person responsible for any pole or post
in any street, thoroughfare, park or other public ground, when the permit
therefor is revoked, or when the use of such pole or post has been or is
abandoned, to remove the pole or post and restore the site thereof to the
satisfaction of the Director of Public Works, without cost to the City. If upon
notification by the Director to do so, any such person, firm or corporation
fails within fifteen days to comply with such notice, the Director shall remove
the pole or post and restore its site, and shall report the cost of doing so to
the Director of Finance and the Director of Law, who shall collect such costs
from such person, in any lawful manner and by any lawful action, together with
the costs of such collection. (1931 Code §22.6361)
   911.09 STATEMENT AND MAP.
   It shall be the duty of every person owning, claiming or using as his own
any pole or post located in any street or thoroughfare, or in any park or other
public grounds of the City, within three months after the passage of this
section, to furnish to the Director of Public Utilities a list or statement of
all poles or posts erected, set or maintained, or used as his own by him,
stating or showing the location, height and purpose of each, and the nature and
number of wires, cables or other fixtures or appurtenances supported by each.
Such list or statement shall be accompanied by a map of the City or of so much
thereof as may be affected, on which the location of each pole or post shall be
exactly located to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Utilities, and to
which can be added the location of poles thereafter erected or acquired. It
shall likewise be the duty of such person, whenever any change is made in the
number of wires, cables, fixtures or appurtenances carried by any pole or post,
to notify the Director of Public Utilities of the changes so made. (1931 Code
§22.6371)
   911.10 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No person shall violate any provision or requirement of this chapter, or to
fail or refuse or neglect to comply with the reasonable directions or demands
of the Director of Public Works or Director of Public Utilities issued pursuant
to the provisions of this chapter.
(1931 Code §22.6391)
   911.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars (100.00).
CHAPTER 913
Trees
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Chapter 913 was repealed by Ordinance 2005-8-85,

CHAPTER 915
Comprehensive Tree and Planting Plan
915.01   Title and statement of purpose.
915.02   Definitions.
915.03   Administration of plan.
915.04   Standards for planting and maintenance in the public way.
915.05   Responsibility for maintenance of plantings in or overhanging the
public way.
915.06   Prohibitions.
915.07   Approved and prohibited plantings in or adjacent to the public way.
915.08   Guidelines for removal of trees in public right of way (curb lawns).
915.081   Appeals.
915.09   Destruction of shrubs, trees, or crops.
915.99   Penalty.
